1012620_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	provide railcar switching services in the United States, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	In addition, we operate a railroad that runs approximately 1,400 miles north south between Tarcoola in South Australia and Darwin in the Northern Territory of Australia.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P0_S2	We operate in 28 states in the United States, four Australian states, one Australian territory and three Canadian provinces and provide rail service at 16 ports in North America and Europe.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	The Company s corporate predecessor was founded in 1899 as a 14-mile rail line serving a single salt mine in upstate New York.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P1_S1	As of December 31, 2010, we operated over approximately 7,400 miles of owned and leased track and approximately 1,400 additional miles under track access arrangements.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P1_S2	Based on North American track miles, we believe that we are the second largest operator of short line and regional freight railroads in North America.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P1_S3	By focusing our corporate and regional management teams on improving our return on invested capital, we intend to continue to increase our earnings and cash flow.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P1_S4	In addition, we expect that acquisitions will adhere to our return on capital targets and that existing operations will improve year-over-year financial returns and safety performance.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P1_S5	The two main drivers of our growth strategy are the execution of our disciplined acquisition and investment strategy as well as our operating strategy.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	Our acquisition and investment strategy includes the acquisition or long-term lease of existing railroads as well as investment in rail equipment and/or track infrastructure to serve customers in new projects.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P2_S1	Opportunities are generally of the following five types:
1012620_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	Other regional railroads or short line railroads, such as our acquisitions of Rail Management Corporation (RMC), the Ohio Central Railroad System (OCR) and CAGY Industries, Inc. (CAGY).
1012620_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	In the United States, there are approximately 500 short line and regional railroads not already owned by us, operating approximately 41,500 miles of track.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	International railroads, such as our acquisition of FreightLink (as defined below) and Rotterdam Rail Feeding (RRF).
1012620_11_ITEM1_P5_S1	We also believe that there are additional acquisition and investment opportunities in Australia, Europe, Canada and other markets outside the United States.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	Rail equipment and/or track infrastructure associated with new industrial and mineral development, such as new mining projects in Australia and North America.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	operating costs and increase equipment utilization.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	In new regions, we target rail properties that have adequate size to establish a presence in the region, provide a platform for growth in the region and attract qualified management.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P7_S2	To help ensure accountability for the projected financial results of our potential acquisitions, we typically include the regional manager who would operate the rail property after the acquisition as part of our due diligence team.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P7_S3	We believe that we are well-positioned to capitalize on additional acquisitions and investments and will continue to adhere to our disciplined approach when evaluating opportunities.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P7_S4	Since 1985, we have completed 35 acquisitions.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P7_S5	In 2010, we acquired certain assets of FreightLink Pty Ltd (FL), Asia Pacific Transport Pty Ltd (APT) and the other APT joint venture sellers (together with FL and APT, FreightLink) in Australia (FreightLink Acquisition).
1012620_11_ITEM1_P7_S6	As a result of the FreightLink Acquisition, we are now the operator of the Tarcoola to Darwin rail line, which links the Port of Darwin to the Australian interstate rail network in South Australia, pursuant to a concession agreement that expires in 2054.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	In each of our regions, we seek to encourage the entrepreneurial drive, local knowledge and customer service that we view as necessary to achieve our financial goals.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	Our railroads operate under strong local management, with centralized administrative support and oversight.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P9_S1	Our regional managers are continually focused on increasing our return on invested capital, earnings and cash flow through the disciplined execution of our operating strategy.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P9_S2	At the regional level, our operating strategy consists of the following four principal elements:
1012620_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	We believe that a safe work environment is essential for our employees, our customers and the communities in which we conduct business.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	Each year we establish stringent safety targets as part of our safety program.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P10_S2	Through the execution of our safety program, we have reduced our injury frequency rate per 200,000 man-hours worked from 5.89 injuries in 1998 to 0.51 in 2010.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	We build each regional rail system on a base of large industrial customers, seek to grow that business through marketing efforts and pursue additional sources of revenue by attracting new customers and providing ancillary rail services.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	These ancillary rail services include railcar switching, repair, storage, cleaning, weighing and blocking and bulk transfer, which enable shippers and Class I carriers to move freight more easily and cost-effectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	Our capacity to compete for new customers is enhanced by the open access environments in both Australia and Europe.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	We focus on lowering operating costs and historically have been able to operate acquired rail lines more efficiently than the companies from which we acquired these properties.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	We typically achieve efficiencies by lowering administrative overhead, consolidating equipment and track maintenance contracts, reducing transportation costs and selling surplus assets.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	We invest in track and rolling stock to ensure that we operate safe railroads that meet the needs of customers.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P14_S1	At the same time, we seek to maximize our return on invested capital by focusing on cost effective capital programs.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P14_S2	For example, we typically rebuild older locomotives rather than purchase new ones and invest in track at levels appropriate for traffic type and density.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P14_S3	In addition, because of the importance of certain customers and railroads to the regional economies, we are able, in some instances, to obtain state and/or federal grants to upgrade track.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P14_S4	Typically, we seek government funds to support investments that otherwise would not be economically viable for us to fund on a stand-alone basis.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	As of December 31, 2010, our continuing operations were organized as nine businesses, which we refer to as regions.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P15_S1	In the United States, we have six regions: Illinois, New York/Ohio/Pennsylvania, Oregon, Rail Link (which includes industrial switching and port operations in various geographic locations), Rocky Mountain and Southern (principally consisting of railroads in the southern part of the United States).
1012620_11_ITEM1_P15_S2	Outside the United States, we have three regions: Australia, Canada (which includes a contiguous railroad located in the United States) and the Netherlands.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	According to the Association of American Railroads (AAR), there are 563 railroads in the United States operating over 139,100 miles of track.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	The AAR classifies railroads operating in the United States into one of three categories (Class I, Regional and Local) based on the amount of revenues and track miles.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	Class I railroads, those with over $378.8 million in revenues, represent approximately 93% of total rail revenues.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P16_S3	Regional and Local railroads combined account for approximately 7% of total rail revenues.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P16_S4	These Regional and Local railroads operate approximately 45,200 miles of track in the United States.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P16_S5	The primary function of these smaller railroads is to provide feeder traffic to the Class I carriers.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	We operate one regional and 56 local (short line) railroads in the United States.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	The following table shows the breakdown of railroads in the United States by classification:
1012620_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	(1) Includes CSX Transportation, BNSF Railway Co., Norfolk Southern, Kansas City Southern Railway Company, Union Pacific Railroad Co., Canadian National Railway and Canadian Pacific.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P18_S1	Source: AAR, Railroad Facts, 2010 Edition.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	The railroad industry in the United States has undergone significant change since the passage of the Staggers Rail Act of 1980 (Staggers Act), which effectively deregulated certain pricing and types of services provided by railroads.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P19_S1	Following the passage of the Staggers Act, Class I railroads in the United States took steps to improve profitability and recapture market share lost to other modes of transportation, primarily trucks.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P19_S2	In furtherance of that goal, Class I railroads focused their management and capital resources on their core long-haul systems, and some of them sold branch lines to short line railroads, whose smaller scale and more cost-efficient operations allowed them to commit the resources necessary to meet the needs of customers located on these lines.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P19_S3	Divestiture of branch lines enabled Class I carriers to minimize incremental capital expenditures, concentrate traffic density, improve operating efficiency and avoid traffic losses associated with rail line abandonment, and spurred the growth in the short line industry.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	According to Rail Trends 2010, published by The Railway Association of Canada (RAC), there are approximately 28,192 miles of track operated by railroads in Canada.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	We operate one regional and two local (short line) railroads in Canada.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	Australia The Australian rail industry encompasses approximately 40,000 kilometers (25,000 miles) of both public and privately owned track linking mainland capital cities as well as regional centers.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	The Australian network comprises three track gauges - broad, standard and narrow.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	There are three major public interstate rail segments in Australia: the east-west corridor from Sydney through Melbourne continuing across to Adelaide and Perth, the north-south corridor along the east coast from Cairns to Melbourne and the Darwin to Adelaide corridor.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	In addition, there are a number of intrastate rail freight networks including those in central Queensland, Victoria, the Hunter Valley in New South Wales, as well as several in Western Australia.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	Adelaide corridor that we operate pursuant to a concession agreement that expires in 2054.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	We are also an accredited rail-service provider in all mainland Australia states and the Northern Territory.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	The Australian rail freight industry is largely open access, and therefore is structured around two components operation of trains for freight haulage (above rail) and the operation and management of rail track access (below rail).
1012620_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	RailCorp (New South Wales) and WestNet Rail (Western Australia).
1012620_11_ITEM1_P25_S2	We are also a participant in the above rail industry along with QR National, Pacific National and SCT Logistics.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P25_S3	Source: BITRE Transport Statistics Yearbook 2009.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	According to ProRail, the entity responsible for the majority of the Dutch rail infrastructure, there are approximately 4,244 miles of track under its control on the Dutch rail network.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	Within the Netherlands, all train operators must have a license from the Inspectie Verkeer en Waterstaat, part of the Netherlands Department of Infrastructure, as well as licenses from ProRail and Keyrail, another rail infrastructure provider.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	According to the trade association, Rail Cargo Information Netherlands, there are currently 12 operators that provide freight rail services in the Netherlands.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P28_S1	OPERATIONS As of December 31, 2010, through our subsidiaries, we owned, leased or operated 62 short line and regional freight railroads with approximately 6,000 miles of track in the United States, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P28_S2	In addition, we operated the approximately 1,400-mile Tarcoola to Darwin rail line, which links the Port of Darwin to the Australian interstate rail network in South Australia.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P28_S3	We also operated through various track access arrangements over approximately 1,400 additional miles of track that is owned or leased by others.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	Freight Revenues We generate revenues primarily from the haulage of freight by rail over relatively short distances.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P29_S1	Freight revenues represented 62.2%, 61.2% and 61.5% of our total revenues in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P29_S2	Non-Freight Revenues We generate non-freight revenues primarily through the following activities:
1012620_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	Other operating income includes, among others, revenues from providing crewing services and track access, as well as management fees.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	Non-freight revenues represented 37.8%, 38.8% and 38.5% of our total operating revenues in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P31_S1	Railcar switching represented 46.5%, 46.6% and 42.4% of our total non-freight revenues in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P31_S2	As of December 31, 2010, our operations served more than 850 freight customers.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P31_S3	Freight revenues from our 10 largest freight customers accounted for approximately 22%, 21% and 20% of our total revenues in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	We typically handle freight pursuant to transportation contracts between us, our connecting carriers and the customer.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P32_S1	These contracts are in accordance with industry norms and vary in duration, with terms ranging from less than one year to 20 years.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P32_S2	These contracts establish a price or, in the case of longer term contracts, a methodology for determining price, but do not typically obligate the customer to move any particular volume.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	Freight rates and volumes are not directly linked to the prices of the commodities being shipped.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	Our railroads transport a wide variety of commodities.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P34_S1	Some of our railroads have a diversified commodity mix while others transport one or two principal commodities.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P34_S2	Our coal and coke commodity revenues accounted for 12%, 10% and 12% of our total revenues in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P34_S3	Our farm and food commodity freight revenues accounted for 9%, 6% and 6% of our total revenues in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P34_S4	For a comparison of freight revenues, carloads and average freight revenues per carload by commodity group for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, see the discussion under Part II.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	The coal and coke commodity group consists primarily of shipments of coal to power plants and industrial customers.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P36_S1	The pulp and paper commodity group consists primarily of outbound shipments of container board and finished papers and inbound shipments of wood pulp.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P36_S2	The metals commodity group consists primarily of finished steel products such as coils, slabs and ingots, and pipe as well as scrap metal.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P36_S3	The minerals and stone commodity group consists primarily of gypsum, salt used in highway ice control, cement, marble, limestone and sand.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P36_S4	The lumber and forest products commodity group consists primarily of export logs, finished lumber, plywood, oriented strand board and particle board used in construction and furniture manufacturing, and wood chips and pulpwood used in paper manufacturing.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P36_S5	The farm and food products commodity group consists primarily of wheat, barley, corn and other grains.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P36_S6	The chemicals and plastics commodity group consists primarily of chemicals used in manufacturing, particularly in the paper industry.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P36_S7	The petroleum products commodity group consists primarily of liquefied petroleum gases, asphalt and crude oil.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P36_S8	The autos and auto parts commodity group consists primarily of finished automobiles and stamped auto parts.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	The metallic ores commodity group consists primarily of alumina, copper, manganese ore, iron ore and nickel ore.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P37_S1	The intermodal commodity group consists of various commodities shipped in trailers or containers on flat cars.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P37_S2	The other commodity group consists of all freight not included in the commodity groups set forth above, such as municipal solid waste, construction demolition and debris and haulage traffic.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	Geographic Information For financial information with respect to each of our geographic areas, see Note 18 to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Part IV.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P38_S1	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules of this Annual Report.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	Traffic Rail traffic shipped on our rail lines can be categorized as interline, local or overhead traffic.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P39_S1	Interline traffic either originates or terminates with customers located along a rail line and is interchanged with other rail carriers.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P39_S2	Local traffic both originates and terminates on the same rail line and does not involve other carriers.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P39_S3	Overhead traffic passes over the line from one connecting rail carrier to another without the carload originating or terminating on the line.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P39_S4	Unlike overhead traffic, interline and local traffic provide us with a more stable source of revenues because this traffic represents shipments to and/or from customers located along our rail lines and is less susceptible to competition from other rail routes or other modes of transportation.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P39_S5	In 2010, revenues generated from interline and local traffic constituted approximately 96% of our freight revenues.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P39_S6	Seasonality of Operations Typically, we experience relatively lower revenues in North America in the first and fourth quarters of each year as the winter season and colder weather in North America tend to reduce shipments of certain products such as construction materials.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P39_S7	In addition, due to adverse winter weather conditions, we also tend to incur higher operating costs during the first and fourth quarters.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P39_S8	We typically initiate capital projects in North America in the second and third quarters when weather conditions are more favorable.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P39_S9	In addition, as a result of the FreightLink Acquisition, we expect to experience relatively lower revenues in Australia in the first quarter of each year as a result of the wet season ( i.e. monsoonal rains).
1012620_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	As of December 31, 2010, our railroads and industrial switching locations had 2,502 full time employees.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P40_S1	Of this total, 878 employees are union members.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	Our railroads have 38 contracts with unions.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P41_S1	We are currently engaged in negotiations with respect to 12 of those agreements.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P41_S2	We are also a party to employee association agreements covering an additional 67 employees who are not represented by a national labor organization.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	The Railway Labor Act (RLA) governs the labor relations of employers and employees engaged in the railroad industry in the United States.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P42_S1	The RLA establishes the right of railroad employees to organize and bargain collectively along craft or class lines and imposes a duty upon carriers and their employees to exert every reasonable effort to make and maintain collective bargaining agreements.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	Le Code Canadian du Travail and the Federal Workplace Relations Act govern the labor relations of employers and employees engaged in the railroad industry in Canada and Australia, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P43_S1	The RLA and foreign labor regulations contain detailed procedures that must be exhausted before a lawful work stoppage may occur.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	In the Netherlands, RRF is not party to any collective bargaining agreements.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	We believe we maintain positive working relationships with our employees.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	SAFETY Our safety program involves all employees and focuses on the prevention of accidents and injuries.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P46_S1	Operating personnel are trained and certified in train operations, the transportation of hazardous materials, safety and operating rules and governmental rules and regulations.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P46_S2	We also participate in safety committees of the AAR, governmental and industry sponsored safety programs and the American Short Line and Regional Railroad Association Safety Committee.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P46_S3	Our reportable injury frequency rate, which is defined by the Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) as reportable injuries per 200,000 man-hours worked, was 0.51 and 0.74 in 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P46_S4	The average injuries per 200,000 man-hours worked for all United States short line railroads was 3.9 in 2010 (through November) and 3.7 in 2009.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	We maintain liability and property insurance coverage.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P47_S1	Our primary liability policies have self-insured retentions of up to $0.5 million per occurrence.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P47_S2	With respect to the transportation of hazardous commodities, our liability policy covers sudden releases of hazardous materials, including expenses related to evacuation, as a result of a railroad accident.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P47_S3	Personal injuries associated with grade crossing accidents are also covered under our liability policies.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P47_S4	Our property damage policies have various self-insured retentions, which vary based on type and location of the incident, that are generally less than $1.0 million.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	Employees of our United States railroads are covered by the Federal Employers Liability Act (FELA), a fault-based system under which claims resulting from injuries and deaths of railroad employees are settled by negotiation or litigation.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P48_S1	FELA-related claims are covered under our liability policies.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P48_S2	Employees of our industrial switching business are covered under workers compensation policies.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P48_S3	Employees of our Canadian railroads are covered by the applicable provincial workers compensation policy.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P48_S4	Employees of our Australian operations are covered by the respective state-based workers compensation legislation in Australia.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P48_S5	Employees of RRF are covered by the workers compensation legislation of the Netherlands.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	We believe our insurance coverage is adequate given our experience and the experience of the rail industry within the geographies we operate.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	In North America, each of our railroads is typically the only rail carrier directly serving our customers.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	In Australia and the Netherlands, however, our customers have access to other rail carriers under the open access regimes.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P50_S2	In addition, our railroads compete directly with other modes of transportation, principally highway competition from motor carriers and, on some routes, ship, barge and pipeline operators.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P50_S3	Competition is based primarily upon the rate charged and the transit time required, as well as the quality and reliability of the service provided.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	Most of the freight we handle is interchanged with other railroads prior to reaching its final destination.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P51_S1	As a result, to the extent that other rail carriers are involved in transporting a shipment, we cannot necessarily control the cost and quality of such service.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	To the extent that highway competition is involved, the degree of that competition is affected by government policies with respect to fuel and other taxes, highway tolls and permissible truck sizes and weights.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P52_S1	To a lesser degree, we also face competition with similar products made in other areas, a kind of competition commonly known as geographic competition.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P52_S2	For example, a paper producer may choose to increase or decrease production at a specific plant served by one of our railroads depending on the relative competitiveness of that plant versus paper plants in other locations.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	In some instances, we face product competition, where commodities we transport are exposed to competition from substitutes.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	In acquiring rail properties, we generally compete with other short line and regional railroad operators and with various financial institutions, including private equity firms, operating in conjunction with short line rail operators.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P54_S1	Competition for rail properties is based primarily upon price and the seller s assessment of the buyer s railroad operating expertise and financing capability.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P54_S2	We believe our established reputation as a successful acquirer and operator of short line rail properties, combined with our managerial and financial resources, effectively positions us to take advantage of acquisition opportunities.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	In addition to environmental laws, securities laws, state and local laws and regulations generally applicable to many businesses, our United States railroads are subject to regulation by:
1012620_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	some state and local regulatory agencies.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	The STB is the successor to certain regulatory functions previously administered by the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC).
1012620_11_ITEM1_P57_S1	Established by the ICC Termination Act of 1995, the STB has jurisdiction over, among other things, certain freight rates (where there is no effective competition), extension or abandonment of rail lines, the acquisition of rail lines and consolidation, merger or acquisition of control of rail common carriers.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P57_S2	In limited circumstances, the STB may condition its approval of an acquisition upon the acquirer of a railroad agreeing to provide severance benefits to certain subsequently terminated employees.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P58_S0	The FRA, DOT and OSHA have jurisdiction over safety, which includes the regulation of equipment standards, track maintenance, handling of hazardous shipments, locomotive and rail car inspection, repair requirements, operating practices and crew qualifications.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P58_S1	The TSA has broad authority over railroad operating practices that have implications for homeland security.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P59_S0	In some cases, state and local laws and regulations may regulate certain aspects of rail operations with respect to health and safety in areas not otherwise regulated by federal law.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P60_S0	On January 12, 2010, the FRA issued final rules governing installation of positive train control (PTC) by the end of 2015.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P60_S1	Although still under development, PTC is a collision avoidance technology intended to override locomotive controls and stop a train before an accident.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P60_S2	Certain of our railroads may be required to install PTC or PTC-related equipment by the end of 2015.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P60_S3	We do not expect that our compliance with the final rules governing the installation of PTC will give rise to any significant financial expenditures.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P61_S0	In addition, in 2010 the STB initiated several proceedings that explore the regulation of railroad operations and competition in the railroad industry.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P61_S1	Congressional initiatives focused on the same topics are also underway.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P61_S2	We are closely monitoring these proceedings and legislation.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P61_S3	The outcome of these initiatives could impact regulation of railroad operations and prices for our rail services, which could undermine the economic viability of certain of our railroads, as well as threaten the service we are able to provide to our customers.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P61_S4	The failure to comply with governmental regulations or changes to the legislative and regulatory environment could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P62_S0	Canada St. Lawrence Atlantic Railroad (Quebec) is a federally regulated railroad and falls under the jurisdiction of the Canada Transportation Agency (CTA) and Transport Canada (TC) and is subject to the Railway Safety Act.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P62_S1	The CTA regulates construction and operation of federally regulated railways, financial transactions of federally regulated railway companies, all aspects of rates, tariffs and services and the transferring and discontinuing of the operation of railway lines.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P62_S2	TC administers the Railway Safety Act, which ensures that federally regulated railway companies abide by all regulations with respect to engineering standards governing the construction or alteration of railway works and the operation and maintenance standards of railway works and equipment.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P63_S0	Quebec Gatineau Railway Inc. and Huron Central Railway Inc. are subject to the jurisdiction of the provincial governments of Quebec and Ontario, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P63_S1	Provincially regulated railways operate only within one province and hold a Certificate of Fitness delivered by a provincial authority.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P63_S2	In the Province of Quebec, the Fitness Certificate is delivered by the Minist re des Transports du Quebec, while in Ontario, under the Shortline Railways Act, 1995, a license must be obtained from the Registrar of Shortline Railways.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P64_S0	Construction, operation and discontinuance of operation are regulated, as are railway services.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P65_S0	Acquisitions of additional railroad operations in Canada, whether federally or provincially regulated, may be subject to review under the Investment Canada Act (ICA), a federal statute that applies to the acquisition of a Canadian business or establishment of a new Canadian business by a non-Canadian.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P65_S1	In the case of an acquisition that is subject to review, a non-Canadian investor must observe a statutory waiting period prior to completion and satisfy the minister responsible for the administration of the ICA that the investment will be of net benefit to Canada, considering certain evaluative factors set out in the legislation.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P65_S2	Any contemplated acquisitions may also be subject to Canada s Competition Act, which contains provisions relating to pre-merger notification as well as substantive merger provisions.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P66_S0	Australia In Australia, regulation of rail safety is generally governed by state legislation and administered by state regulatory agencies.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P66_S1	Our Australian assets are subject to the regulatory regimes governing safety in each of the states and the one territory in which we operate.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P66_S2	Regulation of track access is governed by overriding federal legislation with state-based regimes operating in compliance with the federal legislation.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P66_S3	As a result, with respect to rail infrastructure access, our Australian subsidiaries are also subject to state-based access regimes and federal laws related to access and competition, including Part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act 1974.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P66_S4	In addition, any new acquisitions in Australia will also be subject to review by the Foreign Investment Review Board and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P67_S0	In the Netherlands, we are subject to regulation by the Ministry of Transport, Public Works and Water Management; the Transport, Public Works and Water Management Inspectorate; the Dutch railways manager, ProRail; and Keyrail, the Dutch railways manager for the Betuweroute, a high-speed freight railway connecting the Port of Rotterdam to the German border, and within the Port of Rotterdam.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P67_S1	In addition, at the European level, several directives have been issued concerning the transportation of goods by railway.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P67_S2	These directives generally cover the development of the railways, allocation of railway infrastructure capacity and the levying of charges for the use of railway infrastructure and the licensing of railway undertakings.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P68_S0	The European Union (EU) legislation also sets a framework for a harmonized approach to railway safety.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P68_S1	Every railway company must obtain a safety certification before it can run trains on the European network and EU Member States must set up national railway safety authorities and independent accident investigation bodies.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P68_S2	These directives have been implemented in Dutch railway legislation such as the Railways Act.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P69_S0	The Dutch Competition Authority (DCA) is charged with the supervision of compliance with the European Community s directives on the development of the railways, the allocation of railway infrastructure capacity and the levying of charges for the use of railway infrastructure.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P70_S0	ENVIRONMENTAL MATTERS Our operations are subject to various federal, state, provincial and local laws and regulations relating to the protection of the environment.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P70_S1	In the United States, these environmental laws and regulations, which are implemented principally by the Environmental Protection Agency and comparable state agencies, govern the management of hazardous wastes, the discharge of pollutants into the air and into surface and underground waters and the manufacture and disposal of certain substances.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P70_S2	The primary laws affecting our operations are the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, regulating the management and disposal of solid and hazardous wastes, the Clean Air Act, regulating air emissions and the Clean Water Act, regulating water discharges.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P71_S0	In Canada, environmental laws and regulations are administered at the federal level by Environment Canada and the Ministry of Transport and comparable agencies at the provincial level.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P71_S1	In Australia, these functions are administered primarily by the Department of Transport at the federal level and by environmental protection agencies at the state level.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P72_S0	In the Netherlands, national laws regulating the protection of the environment are administered by the Ministry of Housing, Spatial Planning and the Environment and authorities at the provincial and municipal level, while laws regulating the transportation of hazardous substances are primarily administered by the Ministry of Transport, Public Works and Water Management.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P73_S0	The Commonwealth of Australia has acknowledged that certain portions of the leasehold and freehold land acquired from them and used by our Australian operations contain contamination arising from activities associated with previous operators.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P73_S1	The Commonwealth has carried out certain remediation work to meet existing South Australia environmental standards.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P73_S2	Noncompliance with applicable legal provisions may result in the imposition of fines, temporary or permanent shutdown of operations or other injunctive relief, criminal prosecution or the termination of our concession in Australia.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P73_S3	We believe that the facilities which we operate are in material compliance with applicable environmental laws, regulation and agency agreements.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P73_S4	There are no material environmental claims currently pending or, to our knowledge, threatened against us or any of our railroads.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P73_S5	In addition, we believe our railroads operate in material compliance with current environmental laws and regulations.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P73_S6	We estimate any expenses incurred in maintaining compliance with current environmental laws and regulations will not have a material effect on our earnings or capital expenditures.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P73_S7	We cannot predict the effect, if any, that unidentified environmental matters or the adoption of additional or more stringent environmental laws and regulations would have on the Company s results of operations, cash flows or financial condition.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P74_S0	In August of 2009, we completed the sale of 100% of the share of capital of Ferrocarriles Chiapas Mayab, S.A. de C.V. (FCCM), our Mexican operating subsidiary, to Viablis, S.A. de C.V. (Viablis).
1012620_11_ITEM1_P74_S1	The net assets, results of operations and cash flows on our remaining Mexican subsidiary, GW Servicios S.A. (Servicios), which were classified as discontinued operations, were not material as of and for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P74_S2	We do not expect any material adverse financial impact from Servicios.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P74_S3	Results of our Mexican operations are included in results from discontinued operations.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P75_S0	We were incorporated in Delaware on September 1, 1977.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P75_S1	We completed our initial public offering in June 1996, and since September 27, 2002, our Class A common stock has been listed on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE).
1012620_11_ITEM1_P75_S2	Our principal executive offices and corporate headquarters are located at 66 Field Point Road, Greenwich, Connecticut, 06830, and our telephone number is (203) 629-3722.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P75_S3	Our Internet website address is www.gwrr.com.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P76_S0	We make available free of charge, on or through our Internet website, our annual reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and all amendments to those reports as soon as reasonably practicable after those materials are electronically filed with or furnished to the SEC.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P76_S1	Also, filings made pursuant to Section 16 of the Exchange Act with the SEC by our executive officers, directors and other reporting persons with respect to our common shares are made available, free of charge, through our Internet website.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P76_S2	Our Internet website also contains charters for each of the committees of our Board of Directors, our corporate governance guidelines and our Code of Ethics.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P77_S0	The information regarding our Internet website and its content is for your convenience only.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P77_S1	From time to time, we may use our website as a channel of distribution of material company information.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P77_S2	Financial and other material information regarding the Company is routinely posted on and accessible at www.gwrr.com/investors.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P77_S3	In addition, you may automatically receive email alerts and other information about us by enrolling your email address with us by visiting the E-mail Alerts section at www.gwrr.com/investors.
1012620_11_ITEM1_P78_S0	The information contained on or connected to our Internet website is not deemed to be incorporated by reference in this Annual Report or filed with the SEC.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	statements, including the risks described below and the risks that may be identified in future documents that are filed or furnished with the SEC.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	GENERAL RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH OUR BUSINESS Adverse global macroeconomic and business conditions could negatively impact our business.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The global economy, which experienced a significant downturn starting in late 2008, including widespread recessionary conditions, high levels of unemployment, significant distress of global financial institutions, extreme volatility in security prices, severely diminished liquidity and credit availability, rating downgrades of certain investments and declining valuations of others, began to improve in 2010.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P1_S1	However, while some economic indicators trended positively, the overall rate of global recovery experienced during 2010 has been uneven and uncertainty remains over the stability of the recovery.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P1_S2	There can be no assurance that any of the recent economic improvements will be broad based and sustainable, or that they will enhance conditions in markets relevant to us.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P1_S3	In addition, it is difficult to determine how the general macroeconomic and business conditions will impact our customers, our suppliers and our business in general.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We are required to assess for potential impairment of non-current assets whenever events or changes in circumstances, including economic circumstances, indicate that the respective asset s carrying amount may not be recoverable.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Given the asset intensive nature of our business, weakness in the general economy increases the risk of significant asset impairment charges.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Worsening of current macroeconomic and financial conditions could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P2_S3	If we are unable to consummate additional acquisitions or investments, then we may not be able to implement our growth strategy successfully.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Our growth strategy is based to a large extent on the selective acquisition and development of, and investment in, rail operations, both in new regions and in regions in which we currently operate.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P3_S1	The success of this strategy will depend on, among other things:
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	the availability of management resources to oversee the integration and operation of the new businesses effectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	We may need additional capital to fund our acquisitions and investments.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P4_S2	If we are unable to obtain this capital at a reasonable cost, then we may forego potential opportunities, which would impair the execution of our growth strategy.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Since January 1, 1996, we have acquired interests in 55 railroads, all of which were purchased for cash.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	As of December 31, 2010, we had $27.4 million of cash and cash equivalents and $192.2 million of undrawn revolver capacity available for acquisitions or other activities, subject to maintaining compliance with the covenants under our credit agreement.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	and potential purchases of railroad assets and to attempt to acquire companies and assets that meet our investment criteria.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	As in the past, we expect that we will pay cash for some or all of the purchase price of acquisitions and purchases that we make.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S2	In addition, from time to time we may make investments in equipment and assets to support our customers.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Depending on the number of acquisitions and investments and funding requirements, we may need to raise substantial additional capital.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S4	To the extent that we raise additional capital through the sale of equity or convertible debt securities, the issuance of such securities could result in dilution to our existing stockholders.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S5	If we raise additional funds through the issuance of debt securities, the terms of such debt could impose additional restrictions and costs on our operations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S6	Additional capital, if required, may not be available on acceptable terms or at all.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S7	If we are unable to obtain additional capital, we may forego potential acquisitions, which could impair the execution of our growth strategy.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S8	Our inability to acquire or integrate acquired businesses successfully or to realize the anticipated cost savings and other benefits could have adverse consequences to our business.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S9	We may not be able to acquire or integrate acquired companies or businesses successfully.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S10	Evaluating acquisition targets gives rise to additional costs related to legal, financial, operating and industry due diligence.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S11	In addition, acquisitions generally result in increased operating and administrative costs and, to the extent financed with debt, additional interest costs.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S12	Integrating acquired businesses could also result in significant restructuring costs.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P6_S13	The process of acquiring businesses may be disruptive to our existing business and may cause an interruption or reduction of our business as a result of the following factors, among others:
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	the diversion of management s attention from our day-to-day business as a result of the need to manage any disruptions and difficulties and the need to add management resources to do so.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P7_S1	These disruptions and difficulties, if they occur, may cause us to fail to realize the cost savings, revenue enhancements and other benefits that we expect to result from integrating acquired companies and may cause material adverse short- and long-term effects on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Even if we are able to integrate the operations of acquired businesses into our operations, we may not realize the full benefits of the cost savings, revenue enhancements or other benefits that we may have expected at the time of acquisition.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The expected revenue enhancements and cost savings are based on extensive analyses.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	These analyses necessarily involve assumptions as to future events, including general business and industry conditions, the longevity of specific customer plants and factories served, operating costs and competitive factors, most of which are beyond our control and may not materialize.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P8_S2	While we believe these analyses and their underlying assumptions to be reasonable, they are estimates that are necessarily speculative in nature.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P8_S3	In addition, even if we achieve the expected benefits, we may not be able to achieve them within the anticipated time frame.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Also, the cost savings and other synergies from these acquisitions may be offset by unexpected costs incurred in integrating the companies, increases in other expenses or problems in the business unrelated to these acquisitions.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P8_S5	Finally, the physical conditions of the assets acquired may not be sufficient to support the operations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Many of our recent acquisitions have involved the purchase of stock of existing companies.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P9_S1	These acquisitions, as well as acquisitions of substantially all of the assets of a company, may expose us to liability for actions taken by an acquired business and its management before our acquisition.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	in connection with an acquisition and any contractual guarantees or indemnities that we receive from the sellers of acquired companies may not be sufficient to protect us from, or compensate us for, actual liabilities.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Generally, the representations made by the sellers, other than certain representations related to fundamental matters, such as ownership of capital stock, expire within several years of the closing.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	A material liability associated with an acquisition, especially where there is no right to indemnification, could adversely affect our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our results of operations and rail structure are susceptible to severe weather conditions and other natural occurrences.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	We are susceptible to adverse weather conditions, including floods, fires, hurricanes, droughts, earthquakes and other natural occurrences.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P12_S2	For example, bad weather and natural disasters, such as blizzards in the Northeastern United States and Canada and hurricanes (or cyclones) in the Southeastern United States and Australia, could cause a shutdown or substantial disruption of operations, which could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P12_S3	Even if a material adverse weather or other condition does not directly affect our operations, it can impact the operations of our customers or connecting carriers.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Our minerals and stone revenues may be reduced by mild winters in the Northeastern United States, which lessen demand for road salt.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Our coal and coke revenues may be reduced by mild winters in the Midwestern United States, which lessen demand for coal.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Our revenues generated by our Australian operations are susceptible to the impact of drought conditions on the South Australian grain harvest and the impact of heavy rains and flooding in the Northern Territory.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P15_S1	Furthermore, our expenses could be adversely impacted by such weather conditions, including, for example, higher track maintenance and overtime costs in the winter at our railroads in the Northeastern United States and Canada related to snow removal and mandated work breaks.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P15_S2	Such weather conditions could also cause our customers or connecting carriers to reduce or suspend their operations, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	We are subject to significant governmental regulation of our railroad operations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P16_S1	The failure to comply with governmental regulations or changes to the legislative and regulatory environment could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P16_S2	We are subject to governmental regulation with respect to our railroad operations and to a variety of health, safety, security, labor, environmental and other matters by a significant number of federal, state and local regulatory authorities.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P16_S3	In the United States, these agencies include the STB, DOT, FRA of the DOT, OSHA, DHS and other federal agencies and state departments of transportation.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	In Australia, we are subject to both Commonwealth and state regulations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P17_S1	In Canada, we are subject to regulation by the CTA, TC and the regulatory departments of the provincial governments of Quebec and Ontario.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P17_S2	In the Netherlands, we are subject to regulation by the Ministry of Transport, Public Works and Water Management, the Transport, Public Works and Water Management Inspectorate and Dutch railways managers, ProRail and Keyrail.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P17_S3	Business Regulation for a discussion of these regulations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P17_S4	Our failure to comply with applicable laws and regulations could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	There are various legislative and regulatory actions being considered in the United States, including legislation proposed in the Senate in January 2011 that would modify the regulatory oversight of the rail industry and various proceedings that have been initiated by the STB related to rail competition.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	services, which could undermine the economic viability of certain of our railroads, as well as threaten the service we are able to provide to our customers.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P19_S1	The cost of compliance with the proposed rules and regulations could also be significant.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P19_S2	Federal, state and local regulatory authorities may change the regulatory framework without providing us with any recourse for the adverse effects that the changes may have on our business, including, without limitation, regulatory determinations or rules regarding dispute resolution and business relationships with our customers and other railroads.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P19_S3	As a result, changes to legislation and the regulatory environment could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Our credit agreement and note purchase agreements contain numerous covenants that impose certain restrictions on the way we operate our business.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Our credit agreement contains numerous covenants that impose restrictions on our ability to, among other things:
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Our credit agreement also contains financial covenants that require us to meet a number of financial ratios and tests.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P21_S1	Our failure to comply with the obligations in our credit agreement could result in an increase in our interest expense and could give rise to events of default under the credit agreement, which, if not cured or waived, could permit lenders to accelerate our indebtedness.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P21_S2	We are exposed to the credit risk of our customers and counterparties, and their failure to meet their financial obligations could adversely affect our business.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P21_S3	Our business is subject to credit risk.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P21_S4	There is a risk that customers or counterparties, which include government entities related to grants and financial institutions related to derivative transactions, will fail to meet their obligations when due.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P21_S5	Customers and counterparties that owe us money have defaulted and may continue to default on their obligations to us due to bankruptcy, lack of liquidity, operational failure or other reasons.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P21_S6	We have procedures for reviewing our receivables and credit exposures to specific customers and counterparties; however, default risk may arise from events or circumstances that are difficult to detect or foresee.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P21_S7	Certain of our risk management methods depend upon the evaluation of information regarding markets, customers or other matters.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P21_S8	This information may not, in all cases, be accurate, complete, up-to-date or properly evaluated.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P21_S9	As a result, unexpected credit exposures could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	The loss of important customers or contracts may adversely affect our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Our operations served more than 850 freight customers in 2010.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Freight revenues from our 10 largest freight customers accounted for approximately 22% of our total revenues in 2010.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	We typically handle freight pursuant to transportation contracts between us, our connecting carriers and the customer.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P24_S1	These contracts are in accordance with industry norms and vary in duration.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P24_S2	These contracts establish price or, in the case of longer term contracts, a methodology for determining price, but do not typically obligate the customer to move any particular volume.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Freight rates and volumes are not directly linked to the prices of the commodities being shipped.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Substantial reduction in business with or loss of important customers or contracts could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Because we depend on Class I railroads and other connecting carriers for a majority of our operations, our operating results, financial condition and liquidity may be adversely affected if our relationships with these carriers deteriorate.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	The railroad industry in the United States and Canada is dominated by seven Class I carriers that have substantial market control and negotiating leverage.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P26_S1	In 2010, approximately 85% of our total carloads in the United States and Canada were interchanged with Class I carriers.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P26_S2	A decision by any of these Class I carriers to cease certain freight movements could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P26_S3	The quantitative impact of such a decision would depend on which of our routes and freight movements were affected.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P26_S4	In addition, Class I carriers also have traditionally been significant sources of business for us, as well as sources of potential acquisition candidates as they divest branch lines to smaller rail operators.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Our ability to provide rail service to customers in the United States and Canada depends in large part upon our ability to maintain cooperative relationships with connecting carriers with respect to freight rates, revenue divisions, fuel surcharges, car supply, reciprocal switching, interchange and trackage rights.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Deterioration in the operations of or service provided by those connecting carriers or in our relationship with those connecting carriers could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P27_S2	We are dependent on lease agreements with Class I railroads and other third parties for our operations, strategy and growth.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Our rail operations are dependent, in part, on lease agreements with Class I railroads and third parties that allow us to operate over certain segments of track critical to our operations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P28_S1	For instance, we lease several railroads from Class I carriers under long-term lease arrangements, which collectively accounted for approximately 9% of our 2010 total revenues.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P28_S2	In addition, we own several railroads that also lease portions of the track or right of way upon which they operate from Class I railroads and other third parties.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P28_S3	Our ability to provide comprehensive rail services to our customers on the leased lines depends in large part upon our ability to maintain and extend these lease agreements.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P28_S4	Expiration or termination of these leases or failure of our railroads to comply with the terms of these leases could result in the loss of operating rights with respect to those rail properties.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	We face competition from numerous sources, including those relating to geography, substitute products, other types of transportation and other rail operators.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Each of our railroads is typically the only rail carrier directly serving our customers.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P29_S2	However, in certain circumstances, including under the open access regimes in Australia and the Netherlands, our customers have direct access to other rail carriers.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P29_S3	In addition, our railroads also compete directly with other modes of transportation, principally motor carriers and, on some routes, ship, barge and pipeline operators.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P29_S4	Transportation providers such as motor carriers and barges utilize public rights-of-way that are built and maintained by governmental entities, while we must build and maintain our network.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P29_S5	In addition, competition for our services could increase if other rail operators build new rail lines to access certain of our customers or if legislation is passed that provides materially greater latitude for motor carriers with respect to size or weight restrictions.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	We are also subject to geographic and product competition.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P30_S1	For example, a customer could shift production to a region where we do not have operations or could substitute one commodity for another commodity that is not transported by rail.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P30_S2	In either case, we could lose a source of revenues.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P30_S3	The extent of this competition varies significantly among our railroads.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P30_S4	Competition is based primarily upon the rate charged, the relative costs of substitutable products and the transit time required.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P30_S5	In addition, competition is based on the quality and reliability of the service provided.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P30_S6	Because a significant portion of our carloads in the United States and Canada involve interchange with another carrier, we have only limited control over the total price, transit time or quality of such service.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P30_S7	However, changes to the competitive landscape could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P30_S8	For information on the competition associated with the open access regimes in Australia and Europe, see Additional Risks Associated with our Foreign Operations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S0	It is difficult to quantify the potential impact of competition on our business, since not only each customer, but also each customer location and each product shipped from such location is subject to different types of competition.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S1	Market and regulatory responses to climate change could adversely affect our operating costs and decrease demand for the commodities we transport.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S2	Clean air laws, restrictions, caps, taxes, or other controls on emissions of greenhouse gases, including diesel exhaust, could significantly increase our operating costs.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S3	Restrictions on emissions could also affect our customers that use commodities that we carry to produce energy, use significant amounts of energy in producing or delivering the commodities we carry, or manufacture or produce goods that consume significant amounts of energy or burn fossil fuels, including coal-fired power plants, chemical producers, farmers and food producers and automakers and other manufacturers.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S4	Significant cost increases, government regulation, or changes of consumer preferences for goods or services relating to alternative sources of energy or emissions reductions could materially affect the markets for the commodities we carry, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S5	Government incentives encouraging the use of alternative sources of energy could also affect certain of our customers and the markets for certain of the commodities we carry in an unpredictable manner that could alter our traffic patterns, including, for example, the impacts of ethanol incentives on farming and ethanol producers.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S6	Any of these factors, individually or in conjunction with one or more of the other factors, or other unforeseen impacts of climate change could reduce the amount of traffic we handle.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S7	We could incur significant costs for violations of, or liabilities under, environmental laws and regulations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S8	Our railroad operations and real estate ownership are subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign environmental laws and regulations concerning, among other things, emissions to the air, discharges to waters, the handling, storage, transportation and disposal of waste and other materials and cleanup of hazardous material or petroleum releases.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S9	We may incur environmental liability from conditions or practices at properties previously owned or operated by us, properties leased by us and other properties owned by third parties (for example, properties at which hazardous substances or wastes for which we are responsible have been treated, stored, spilled or disposed), as well as at properties currently owned by us.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P31_S10	Under some environmental statutes, such liability may be found without regard to whether we were at fault and may also be joint and several, whereby we are responsible for all the liability at issue even though we (or the entity that gives rise to our liability) may be only one of a number of entities whose conduct contributed to the liability.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Environmental requirements and liabilities could obligate us to incur significant costs, including significant expenses to investigate and remediate environmental contamination, which could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P32_S1	Exposure to market risks, particularly changes in interest rates and foreign currency exchange rates, and hedging transactions entered into to mitigate such risks could adversely impact our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We are exposed to various market risks, including interest rate and foreign currency exchange rate risks.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P33_S1	It is impossible to fully mitigate all such exposure and higher interest rates and unfavorable fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates could have an adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P34_S0	From time to time, we may use various financial instruments to reduce our exposure to certain market risks.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P34_S1	While these financial instruments reduce the Company s exposure to market risks, the use of such instruments may ultimately limit the Company s ability to benefit from lower interest rates or favorable foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations due to amounts fixed at the time of entering into the hedge agreement, which could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P35_S0	We may be adversely affected by diesel fuel supply constraints resulting from disruptions in the fuel markets and increases in diesel fuel costs.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P35_S1	We consumed 18.5 million gallons of diesel fuel in 2010.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Fuel availability could be affected by any limitation in the fuel supply or by any imposition of mandatory allocation or rationing regulations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P36_S1	If a severe fuel supply shortage arose from production curtailments, disruption of oil imports, disruption of domestic refinery production, damage to refinery or pipeline infrastructure, political unrest, war or otherwise, diesel fuel may not be readily available and may be subject to rationing regulations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P36_S2	In addition, diesel fuel costs constitute a significant portion of our total operating expenses and an increase in diesel fuel costs could have a negative effect on our profitability.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P36_S3	Although we receive fuel surcharges and other rate adjustments to offset rising fuel prices, if Class I railroads change their policies regarding fuel surcharges, the compensation we receive for increases in fuel costs may decrease.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P36_S4	Costs for fuel used in operations were approximately 9% and 8% of our operating expenses for the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P36_S5	If diesel fuel prices increase dramatically from production curtailments, a disruption of oil imports or otherwise, these events could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P37_S0	As a common carrier by rail, we are required to transport hazardous materials, regardless of risk.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P37_S1	Transportation of certain hazardous materials could create catastrophic losses in terms of personal injury, property damage and environmental remediation costs and compromise critical parts of our railroads.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P37_S2	In addition, insurance premiums charged for some or all of the coverage currently maintained by us could increase dramatically or certain coverage may not be available to us in the future if there is a catastrophic event related to rail transportation of these commodities.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P37_S3	In addition, federal regulators have previously prescribed regulations governing railroads transportation of hazardous materials and have the ability to put in place additional regulations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P37_S4	For instance, recently enacted legislation requires pre-notification for hazardous materials shipments.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P37_S5	Such legislation and regulations could impose significant additional costs on railroads.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P37_S6	Additionally, regulations adopted by the DOT and the DHS could significantly increase the costs associated with moving hazardous materials on our railroads.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P37_S7	Further, certain local governments have sought to enact ordinances banning hazardous materials moving by rail within their borders.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P37_S8	Such ordinances could require the re-routing of hazardous materials shipments, with the potential for significant additional costs.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P37_S9	Increases in costs associated with the transportation of hazardous materials could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P38_S0	The occurrence of losses or other liabilities that are either not covered by insurance or that exceed our insurance limits could materially adversely affect our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P38_S1	We have obtained for each of our railroads insurance coverage for losses arising from personal injury and for property damage in the event of derailments or other accidents or occurrences.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P39_S0	On certain of the rail lines over which we operate, freight trains are commingled with passenger trains.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P39_S1	For instance, in Oregon we operate certain passenger trains for the Tri-County Metropolitan Transportation District of Oregon over our Portland Western Railroad.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P39_S2	Unexpected or catastrophic circumstances such as accidents involving passenger trains or spillage of hazardous materials could cause our liability to exceed expected statutory limits, third-party insurance limits and our insurance limits.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P39_S3	Also, insurance is available from only a very limited number of insurers, and we may not be able to obtain insurance protection at our current levels or obtain it on terms acceptable to us.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P39_S4	In addition, subsequent adverse events directly and indirectly attributable to us may result in additional increases in our insurance premiums and/or our self-insured retentions and could result in limitations to the coverage under our existing policies.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P39_S5	Unless it is extended, the expiration of the short line tax credit on December 31, 2011, will increase our effective tax rate.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Since 2005, we have benefited from the effects of the short line tax credit, which is an income tax credit for Class II and Class III railroads to reduce their federal income tax based on qualified railroad track maintenance expenditures (the Short Line Tax Credit).
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P40_S1	Qualified expenditures include amounts incurred for maintaining track, including roadbed, bridges and related track structures owned or leased by a Class II or Class III railroad.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P40_S2	The credit is equal to 50% of the qualified expenditures, subject to an annual limitation of $3,500 multiplied by the number of miles of railroad track owned or leased by the Class II or Class III railroad as of the end of their tax year.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P40_S3	In 2010 and 2009, the Short Line Tax Credit lowered our effective tax rate by 9.3% and 15.0%, respectively.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P40_S4	The most recent extension of the Short Line Tax Credit only extends the credit through December 31, 2011.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P40_S5	If the Short Line Tax Credit is not extended for additional tax years, the loss of the credit will increase our effective tax rate and reduce our reported earnings per share.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Certain of our capital projects may be impacted by our ability to obtain government funding.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S1	Certain of our existing capital projects are, and certain of our future capital projects may be partially or completely funded through government grant programs.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S2	During 2010, we obtained government funding for 63 separate projects that were partially funded by United States and Canadian federal, state and municipal agencies.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S3	The spending associated with these grant-funded projects represented approximately 37% of our total capital expenditures during 2010.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S4	Government funding for projects is limited, and there is no guarantee that budget pressure at the federal, state and local level or changing governmental priorities will not eliminate funding availability.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S5	In addition, competition for government funding from other short line railroads, Class I railroads and other companies is significant, and the receipt of government funds is often contingent on the acceptance of contractual obligations that may not be strictly profit maximizing.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S6	In certain jurisdictions, the acceptance of government funds may impose additional legal obligations on our operations, such as compliance with prevailing wage requirements.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S7	If we are unable to obtain adequate government funding, we may have to defer or forgo such capital projects.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S8	Some of our employees belong to labor unions, and strikes or work stoppages could adversely affect our operating results, financial condition and liquidity.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S9	We are a party to collective bargaining agreements with various labor unions in the United States, Australia and Canada.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S10	In North America, we are party to 37 contracts with national labor organizations.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S11	We are currently engaged in negotiations with respect to 12 of those agreements.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P41_S12	We have also entered into employee association agreements with an additional 67 employees who are not represented by a national labor organization.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P42_S0	GWA has a collective enterprise bargaining agreement covering the majority of its employees.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S0	acceptable contracts with these unions could result in, among other things, strikes, work stoppages or other slowdowns by the affected workers.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S1	If the unionized workers were to engage in a strike, work stoppage or other slowdown, or other employees were to become unionized, or the terms and conditions in future labor agreements were renegotiated, we could experience a significant disruption of our operations and/or higher ongoing labor costs.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S2	To date, we have experienced no material strikes or work stoppages.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S3	We are also subject to the risk of the unionization of our non-unionized employees.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S4	Additional unionization of our workforce could result in higher employee compensation and restrictive working condition demands that could increase our operating costs or constrain our operating flexibility.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S5	If we are unable to employ a sufficient number of skilled workers, our operating results, financial condition and liquidity may be materially adversely affected.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S6	We believe that our success and our growth depend upon our ability to attract and retain skilled workers who possess the ability to operate and maintain our equipment and facilities.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S7	The operation and maintenance of our equipment and facilities involve complex and specialized processes and often must be performed in harsh conditions, resulting in a high employee turnover rate when compared to many other industries.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S8	The challenge of attracting and retaining the necessary workforce is increased by the expected retirement of an aging workforce and significant competition for specialized trades.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S9	Within the next five years, we estimate that approximately 19% of the current workforce will become eligible for retirement.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S10	Many of these workers hold key operating positions, such as conductors, engineers and mechanics.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S11	In addition, the demand for workers with the types of skills we require has increased, especially from Class I railroads, which can usually offer higher wages and better benefits.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S12	A significant increase in the wages paid by competing employers could result in a reduction of our skilled labor force or an increase in the wage rates that we must pay or both.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S13	If any of these events were to occur, our cost structure could increase, our profit margins could decrease and our growth strategy could be impaired.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S14	Our operations are dependent on our ability to obtain rail cars, locomotives and other critical railroad items from suppliers.
1012620_11_ITEM1A_P43_S15	Due to the capital intensive nature and industry-specific requirements of the rail industry, there are high barriers of entry for potential new suppliers of core railroad items such as rail cars, locomotives and track materials.
