1012620_16_ITEM7_P24_S2	The results of operations from Pinsly Arkansas have been included in our consolidated statement of operations since the acquisition date within our North American Operations segment.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P24_S3	For additional information regarding Pinsly Arkansas, see Note 3 , Changes in Operations , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P24_S4	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	Rapid City, Pierre Eastern Railroad, Inc.:
1012620_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	On May 30, 2014, our new subsidiary, RCP E, purchased the assets comprising the western end of Canadian Pacific Railway Limited's (CP) Dakota, Minnesota Eastern Railroad Corporation (DM E) rail line for a cash purchase price of $218.6 million , including the purchase of materials and supplies, railcars, equipment and vehicles.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P26_S1	RCP E commenced freight service on the line on June 1, 2014.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P26_S2	The results of operations from RCP E have been included in our consolidated statement of operations since the acquisition date within our North American Operations segment.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P26_S3	For additional information regarding RCP E, see Note 3 , Changes in Operations , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P26_S4	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	Australia Arrium Limited: Between 2011 and 2014, our subsidiary, Genesee Wyoming Australia Pty Ltd (GWA), invested a total of A$78.0 million (or $77.7 million at the exchange rates on the dates the spending occurred) to purchase locomotives and railcars, as well as to construct a standard gauge rolling-stock maintenance facility to support iron ore shipments from Arrium's Southern Iron mine and Whyalla-based operations, which include the Middleback Range iron ore mines and the Whyalla steelworks.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	Arrium mothballed its Southern Iron mine in April 2015, citing the significant decline in the price of iron ore, while the mines in the Middleback Range continued to operate.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P28_S1	During 2015, GWA carried approximately 8,300 carloads of iron ore from the Southern Iron mine and, in total, generated approximately A$83 million in freight and freight-related revenues (or approximately $62 million , at the average exchange rate for the year ended December 31, 2015) under the fixed and variable payment structure that is customary in large contracts in Australia.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P28_S2	We expect to receive only the fixed portion of the revenue following the mothballing of the Southern Iron mine and both the fixed and variable portion from the Whyalla-based operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P28_S3	We could lose some or all of this revenue if Arrium continues to suffer from declines in commodity prices or other economic and financial conditions.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	In February 2016, Arrium announced a recapitalization plan with GSO Capital Partners LP.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P29_S1	The recapitalization plan is subject to a variety of closing conditions, including approval by Arrium s existing lenders, as well as regulatory and other approvals.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P29_S2	The following table breaks down our operating revenues and total carloads into new operations and existing operations for the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	Operating Expenses Total operating expenses for the year ended December 31, 2015 increased $398.7 million , or 32.7% , to $1,616.1 million , compared with $1,217.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P30_S1	The increase included $530.0 million from new operations, partially offset by a decrease of $131.3 million from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P31_S0	When we discuss expenses from existing operations, we are referring to the change in our expenses, period-over-period, associated with operations that we managed in both periods (excluding the impact of acquisitions).
1012620_16_ITEM7_P31_S1	The decrease from existing operations was primarily due to a decrease of $54.4 million from the depreciation of foreign currencies relative to the United States dollar and decreases of $54.8 million in diesel fuel used in train operations, $11.4 million in materials, $10.7 million in purchased services, $10.2 million in trackage rights and $9.0 million in equipment rents, partially offset by increases of $13.1 million in depreciation and amortization and $8.2 million in other expenses.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P32_S0	The following table sets forth our total operating expenses for the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_16_ITEM7_P33_S0	Income from Operations/Operating Ratio Income from operations was $384.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $421.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P33_S1	Income from operations for the year ended December 31, 2015 included acquisition-related costs associated with Freightliner of $12.6 million , business development and related costs of $7.0 million and net gain on sale of assets of $2.3 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P33_S2	Income from operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 included business development and related costs of $5.2 million and net gain on sale of assets of $5.1 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P33_S3	Our operating ratio was 80.8% for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with 74.3% for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P33_S4	The increase in our operating ratio was primarily driven by lower operating margins from Freightliner, as our U.K./European Operations primarily use leased equipment .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P33_S5	Our same railroad operating ratio in the year ended December 31, 2015 was 76.2% , compared with 74.3% for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P33_S6	Interest Expense Interest expense was $67.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $56.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P33_S7	The increase in interest expense was primarily due to a higher debt balance resulting from the acquisition of Freightliner.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P34_S0	Provision for Income Taxes Our income tax provision for the year ended December 31, 2015 was $75.9 million , which represented 25.2% of income before income taxes.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P34_S1	Our provision for income taxes for the year ended December 31, 2015 included a $27.4 million tax benefit from the United States Short Line Tax Credit, which had previously expired on December 31, 2014 and was extended in December 2015 for fiscal years 2015 and 2016, and a $9.7 million tax benefit associated with a prospective change in U.K. tax rates enacted during the fourth quarter of 2015.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P34_S2	Our income tax provision for the year ended December 31, 2014 was $107.1 million , which represented 29.1% of income before income taxes.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P34_S3	Our provision for income taxes for the year ended December 31, 2014 included a $27.0 million tax benefit associated with the United States Short Line Tax Credit and a $3.9 million tax benefit as a result of receiving consent from the United States IRS to change a tax accounting method retroactively for companies acquired as a result of the RailAmerica acquisition.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P34_S4	For additional information regarding the United States Short Line Tax Credit, see Note 13 , Income Taxes , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P34_S5	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P35_S0	The United States Short Line Tax Credit is an income tax track maintenance credit for Class II and Class III railroads to reduce their federal income tax based on qualified railroad track maintenance expenditures.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P35_S1	Qualified expenditures include amounts incurred for maintaining track, including roadbed, bridges and related track structures owned or leased by a Class II or Class III railroad.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P35_S2	The credit is equal to 50% of the qualified expenditures, subject to an annual limitation of $3,500 multiplied by the number of miles of railroad track owned or leased by the Class II or Class III railroad as of the end of its tax year.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P36_S0	The United States Short Line Tax Credit was in existence from 2005 through 2014 and was further extended in December 2015 for fiscal years 2015 and 2016.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P36_S1	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2015 was $225.0 million , compared with $260.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P36_S2	Our basic EPS were $3.97 with 56.7 million weighted average shares outstanding for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with basic EPS of $4.71 with 55.3 million weighted average shares outstanding for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P36_S3	Our diluted EPS for the year ended December 31, 2015 were $3.89 with 57.8 million weighted average shares outstanding, compared with diluted EPS of $4.58 with 57.0 million weighted average shares outstanding for the year ended December 31, 2014 .

1012620_16_ITEM7_P39_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in our North American Operations freight revenues by commodity group segregated into new operations and existing operations for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with the year ended December 31, 2014 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_16_ITEM7_P40_S0	Total traffic from our North American Operations decreased 134,757 carloads, or 7.6% , for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with the same period in 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P40_S1	The decrease consisted of a decrease of 194,309 carloads, or 10.9% , from existing operations, partially offset by 59,552 carloads from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P40_S2	The decrease in traffic from existing operations was principally due to decreases of 88,517 carloads of coal and coke traffic, 52,249 carloads of metals traffic, 19,552 carloads of other commodity traffic, 10,098 carloads of agricultural products traffic, 7,398 carloads of minerals and stone traffic, 6,732 carloads of autos and auto parts traffic, 5,960 carloads of lumber and forest products traffic and 2,325 carloads of petroleum products traffic, partially offset by an increase of 2,549 of metallic ores traffic.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P40_S3	All remaining traffic decreased by a net 4,027 carloads.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S0	The following information discusses the significant changes in our North American Operations freight revenues from existing operations by commodity group excluding the impact of foreign currency.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S1	Changes in average freight revenues per carload in a commodity group can be impacted by changes in customer rates and fuel surcharges, as well as changes in the mix of customer traffic within a commodity group.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S2	Average freight revenues per carload from our North American Operations increased 2.9% to $577 for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S3	Average freight revenues per carload from existing operations increased 2.7% to $576.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S4	The increase in average freight revenues per carload from existing operations was impacted by a change in mix, which increased average freight revenues per carload 1.7%, partially offset by lower fuel surcharges, which decreased average freight revenues per carload 4.8%.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S5	Excluding these factors, average freight revenues per carload from existing operations increased 5.8%.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S6	Agricultural products revenues decreased $9.7 million , or 8.1% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S7	Agricultural products traffic volume decreased 10,098 carloads, or 4.8%, which decreased revenues by $5.6 million, and average freight revenues per carload decreased 3.5%, which decreased revenues by $4.1 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S8	The carload decrease was primarily due to decreased shipments in the midwestern and western United States due to weaker grain prices.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S9	Autos and auto parts revenues decreased $5.7 million , or 24.9% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S10	Autos and auto parts traffic volume decreased 6,732 carloads, or 19.5%, which decreased revenues by $4.2 million, and average freight revenues per carload decreased 6.7%, which decreased revenues by $1.5 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S11	The carload decrease was primarily due to decreased export shipments in the western United States and weather-related delays which impacted car supply in the midwestern United States in early 2015.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S12	Coal and coke revenues decreased $32.4 million , or 25.7% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S13	Coal and coke traffic volume decreased 88,517 carloads, or 24.9%, which decreased revenues by $31.0 million, and average freight revenues per carload decreased 1.1%, which decreased revenues by $1.4 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S14	The carload decrease was primarily due to decreased demand for steam coal as a result of competition from natural gas power generation.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S15	Lumber and forest products revenues decreased $5.5 million , or 6.8% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S16	Lumber and forest products traffic volume decreased 5,960 carloads, or 4.4%, which decreased revenues by $3.5 million, and average freight revenues per carload decreased 2.5%, which decreased revenues by $2.0 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S17	The carload decrease was primarily due to decreased shipments to the west coast housing market and decreased shipments in the southern United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S18	Metallic ores revenues increased $2.4 million , or 13.7% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S19	Metallic ores traffic volume increased 2,549 carloads, or 11.5%, which increased revenues by $2.0 million, and average freight revenues per carload increased 1.9%, which increased revenues by $0.3 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S20	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased copper concentrate shipments in the western United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S21	Metals revenues decreased $26.3 million , or 20.4% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S22	Metals traffic volume decreased 52,249 carloads, or 28.4%, which decreased revenues by $40.7 million, while average freight revenues per carload increased 11.3%, which increased revenues by $14.4 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P41_S23	The carload decrease was driven by weaker shipments of steel and scrap resulting primarily from competition from imported steel.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	The increase in average freight revenues per carload was primarily driven by a change in the mix of business.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P42_S1	Minerals and stone revenues decreased $8.4 million , or 7.4% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P42_S2	Minerals and stone average freight revenues per carload decreased 3.6%, which decreased revenues by $4.3 million, and traffic volume decreased by 7,398 carloads, or 3.8%, which decreased revenues by $4.1 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P42_S3	The decrease in carloads was primarily due to decreased shipments of frac sand and proppants in the midwestern and southern United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S0	Other commodity group revenues decreased $1.3 million , or 6.3% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S1	Other traffic decreased 19,552 carloads, or 22.2%, which decreased revenues by $5.6 million, while average freight revenues per carload increased 20.4%, which increased revenues by $4.3 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S2	The change was primarily due to decreased overhead Class I traffic in the central United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S3	Petroleum products increased $5.4 million , or 8.7% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S4	Petroleum products average freight revenues per carload increased 11.3%, which increased revenues by $6.9 million, while traffic volume decreased 2,325 carloads, or 2.2%, which decreased revenues by $1.5 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S5	Average revenues per carload increased primarily due to the change in mix of business, which resulted from a decrease in crude oil shipments in Canada and the western and southern United States and increased shipments of liquid petroleum gas and natural gas liquids in the midwestern and northeastern United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S6	Freight revenues from all remaining commodities combined decreased by a net $3.2 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S7	Freight-Related Revenues Excluding a $4.0 million decrease due to the impact from foreign currency depreciation, freight-related revenues from our North American Operations, which includes revenues from railcar switching, track access rights, crewing services, storage and other ancillary revenues related to the movement of freight, increased $16.8 million , or 8.0% , to $227.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S8	The increase in freight-related revenues consisted of $10.8 million from existing operations and $5.9 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S9	The increase in freight-related revenues from existing operations was primarily due to an increase in demurrage and storage revenues and an increase in trackage rights revenues due to a new customer contract.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S10	All Other Revenues Excluding a $1.2 million decrease due to the impact of foreign currency depreciation, all other revenues from our North American Operations, which includes revenues from third-party car and locomotive repairs, property rentals, railroad construction and other ancillary revenues not directly related to the movement of freight, decreased $15.3 million , or 18.9% , to $65.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S11	The decrease in all other revenues consisted of $16.9 million from existing operations, partially offset by $1.6 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S12	The decrease in all other revenues from existing operations was primarily due to a decrease in construction revenues as a result of fewer third-party projects in 2015, which resulted from our previously disclosed decision to focus our construction resources on internal projects, and a decrease in rental revenues.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S13	Operating Expenses Total operating expenses from our North American Operations decreased $27.2 million , or 2.8% , to $944.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $971.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S14	The decrease included $59.1 million from existing operations, partially offset by an increase of $31.9 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P43_S15	The decrease from existing operations was primarily due to a $46.5 million decrease in fuel costs and the depreciation of the Canadian dollar relative to the United States dollar, which resulted in a $13.5 million decrease in operating expenses from existing operations.

1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S2	The increase consisted of $11.9 million from new operations and $0.4 million from existing operations.

1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S7	Purchased services expense was $64.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $61.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $2.3 million , or 3.8% .

1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S10	Depreciation and amortization expense was $141.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $125.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $16.7 million , or 13.4% .

1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S12	The increase from existing operations was primarily attributable to capital expenditures in 2014.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S13	The cost of diesel fuel used in train operations was $75.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $118.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , a decrease of $43.2 million , or 36.3% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S14	The decrease consisted of $46.5 million from existing operations, partially offset by $3.4 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S15	The decrease from existing operations was primarily attributable to a 36.2% decrease in average fuel cost per gallon.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S16	Materials expense was $57.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $68.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , a decrease of $11.1 million , or 16.1% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S17	The decrease consisted of $14.3 million from existing operations, partially offset by $3.3 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S18	The decrease from existing operations was primarily attributable to a reduction in the level of car repairs and construction projects in 2015.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S19	Trackage rights expense was $24.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $28.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , a decrease of $4.3 million , or 14.9% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P45_S20	The decrease consisted of $4.3 million from existing operations primarily attributable to reduced traffic for a metals customer in the southern United States and reduced coal traffic due to a maintenance outage at a power plant we serve.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P46_S0	Other expenses were $89.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $74.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $14.7 million , or 19.8% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P46_S1	The increase consisted of $13.1 million from existing operations and $1.6 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P46_S2	The increase from existing operations was primarily attributable to an increase in acquisition and integration costs as a result of the Freightliner acquisition.

1012620_16_ITEM7_P46_S5	Income from operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 included business development and related costs of $4.9 million and net gain on sale of assets of $4.6 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P46_S6	The operating ratio was 76.0% for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with 74.5% for the year ended December 31, 2014 .

1012620_16_ITEM7_P50_S0	The following information discusses the significant changes in our Australian Operations freight revenues from existing operations by commodity group excluding the impact of foreign currency.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P50_S1	Changes in average freight revenues per carload in a commodity group can be impacted by changes in customer rates and fuel surcharges, as well as changes in the mix of customer traffic within a commodity group.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P50_S2	Average freight revenues per carload from our Australian Operations decreased 18.0% to $731 for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P50_S3	The decrease in average freight revenues per carload was impacted by a change in mix, which decreased average freight revenues per carload 15.4%, and lower fuel surcharges, which decreased average freight revenues per carload 2.6%.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P50_S4	Agricultural products revenues decreased $4.2 million , or 15.6% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P50_S5	Agricultural products average freight revenues per carload decreased 11.3%, which decreased revenues by $3.0 million, and traffic volume decreased 2,650 carloads, or 4.9%, which decreased revenues by $1.2 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P50_S6	The decrease in average freight revenues per carload was primarily attributable to a change in the mix of business.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P50_S7	Intermodal revenues decreased $5.1 million , or 6.6% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P50_S8	Intermodal average freight revenues per carload decreased 3.9%, which decreased revenues by $3.0 million, and traffic volume decreased 1,816 carloads, or 2.9%, which decreased revenues by $2.1 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P50_S9	The decrease in average freight revenues per carload was primarily due to lower fuel surcharges.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S0	Metallic ores revenues decreased $46.9 million , or 51.5% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S1	Metallic ores traffic decreased 29,627 carloads, or 52.4%, which decreased revenues by $48.7 million, while average freight revenues per carload increased 1.9%, which increased revenues by $1.8 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S2	The carload decrease was primarily due to decreased iron ore and manganese shipments as a result of multiple customer mine closures.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S3	Freight revenues from all remaining commodities combined decreased by less than $0.1 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S4	Freight-Related Revenues Excluding a $9.3 million decrease due to the impact of foreign currency depreciation, freight-related revenues from our Australian Operations, which includes revenues from railcar switching, track access rights, crewing services, storage and other ancillary revenues related to the movement of freight, increased $41.4 million , or 89.6% , to $87.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S5	The increase in freight-related revenues consisted of $36.1 million from new operations and $5.3 million from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S6	The increase in freight-related revenues from existing operations was primarily due to $15.1 million of fixed payments received under a customer contract following discontinuation of carload shipments due to a mine closure, partially offset by an $8.1 million decrease in crewing revenue and a $2.0 million decrease in trackage rights.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S7	All Other Revenues Excluding a $2.3 million decrease due to the impact of foreign currency depreciation, all other revenues from our Australian Operations, which includes revenues from third-party railcar and locomotive repairs, property rentals and other ancillary revenues not directly related to the movement of freight, decreased $3.3 million , or 27.8% , to $8.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S8	The decrease was primarily due to a reduction in third-party construction activities in 2015.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S9	Operating Expenses Total operating expenses from our Australian Operations for the year ended December 31, 2015 decreased $34.8 million , or 15.6% , to $188.1 million , compared with $222.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S10	The decrease consisted of $69.3 million from existing operations, partially offset by $34.6 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S11	The decrease from existing operations was primarily due to a $37.2 million decrease from the depreciation of the Australian dollar relative to the United States dollar.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P51_S12	The following table sets forth operating expenses from our Australian Operations for the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S0	The following information discusses the significant changes in operating expenses of our Australian Operations excluding a $37.2 million decrease due to the impact from foreign currency depreciation.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S1	Labor and benefits expense was $67.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $59.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $8.7 million , or 14.7% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S2	The increase consisted of $12.4 million from new operations, partially offset by a decrease of $3.7 million from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S3	The decrease from existing operations was primarily due to decreased headcount as a result of changes made to the operating plans in Australia associated with mine closures, partially offset by severance costs and increased headcount due to the insourcing of equipment maintenance activities.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S4	Equipment rents expense was $12.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $8.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $4.0 million , or 48.1% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S5	The increase consisted of $6.9 million from new operations, partially offset by a decrease of $2.9 million from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S6	The decrease from existing operations was primarily the result of the purchase of previously leased railcars and the termination of a rail car lease following a customer mine closure.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S7	Purchased services expense was $19.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $28.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , a decrease of $9.1 million , or 31.7% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S8	The decrease consisted of $10.1 million from existing operations, partially offset by $1.0 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S9	The decrease from existing operations was primarily attributable to the insourcing of equipment maintenance activities.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S10	Depreciation and amortization was $27.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $23.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $4.0 million , or 17.0% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S11	The increase consisted of $2.8 million from new operations and $1.2 million from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S12	The increase from existing operations was primarily attributable to capital expenditures in 2014.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S13	The cost of diesel fuel used in train operations was $21.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $22.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , a decrease of $0.8 million , or 3.8% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S14	The decrease consisted of $8.0 million from existing operations, partially offset by $7.2 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S15	The decrease from existing operations consisted of $6.5 million due to a 29.2% decrease in average fuel cost per gallon and $1.6 million due to a 10.4% decrease in diesel fuel consumption.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S16	Materials expense was $11.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $6.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $5.1 million , or 81.3% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S17	The increase consisted of $2.8 million from existing operations and $2.3 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S18	The increase from existing operations was primarily attributable to the insourcing of equipment maintenance activities.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S19	Trackage rights expense was $13.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $18.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , a decrease of $5.2 million , or 28.1% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S20	The decrease consisted of $6.1 million from existing operations, partially offset by $1.0 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S21	The decrease from existing operations was primarily attributable to decreased shipments as a result of an iron ore customer mine closure in South Australia that moves over a segment of track owned by a third party.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S22	Other expenses were $6.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $10.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , a decrease of $4.2 million , or 38.5% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S23	The decrease consisted of $4.8 million from existing operations, partially offset by $0.6 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S24	The decrease from existing operations was primarily attributable to reduced costs associated with third-party track projects in 2015.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S25	Income from Operations/Operating Ratio Income from operations from our Australian Operations was $54.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $90.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S26	Included in the decrease from income from operations is a $15.1 million net decrease due to the impact from foreign currency depreciation.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S27	Income from operations for the year ended December 31, 2015 and 2014 included $2.7 million and $0.3 million , respectively, of business development and related costs.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S28	The operating ratio was 77.4% for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with 71.1% for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P52_S29	The higher operating ratio was primarily driven by lower iron ore freight revenues.

1012620_16_ITEM7_P55_S0	The freight revenues from our U.K./European Operations were comprised entirely of our Freightliner U.K./European Operations for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P55_S1	Freight revenues from our U.K./European Operations primarily consisted of intermodal traffic, minerals and stone traffic, which includes construction aggregates, and coal.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P55_S2	There were no freight revenues from our U.K./European Operations for 2014, as all of our U.K./European Operations revenues were freight-related in 2014.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P55_S3	Freight-Related Revenues Freight-related revenues from our U.K./European Operations includes port switching as well as traction service (or hook and pull service that requires us to provide locomotives and drivers to move a customer's train between specified origin and destination points).
1012620_16_ITEM7_P55_S4	Freight-related revenues from our U.K./European Operations also include infrastructure services, where we operate work trains for the track infrastructure owner, drayage and other ancillary revenues related to the movement of freight.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P55_S5	With the exception of infrastructure services, which are primarily in the U.K., freight-related revenues from our U.K./European Operations are primarily associated with the Continental European intermodal business.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P55_S6	Excluding a $3.5 million decrease due to the impact of foreign currency depreciation, freight-related revenues from our U.K./European Operations increased $165.3 million to $182.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , primarily due to our new Freightliner operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P56_S0	All Other Revenues All other revenues from our U.K./European Operations, which includes revenues from third-party railcar and locomotive repairs, property rentals and other ancillary revenues not directly related to the movement of freight, consisted of $23.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , as a result of our new Freightliner operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P56_S1	Operating Expenses Total operating expenses from our U.K./European Operations were $483.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with $23.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $460.7 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P56_S2	The increase included $463.6 million from new operations, partially offset by a decrease of $2.9 million from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P56_S3	The overall net decrease from existing operations was primarily due to the depreciation of the Euro relative to the United States dollar.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P56_S4	The following table sets forth operating expenses from our U.K./European Operations for the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_16_ITEM7_P57_S0	Equipment rents expense consists primarily of costs associated with Freightliner's predominately leased locomotive and railcar fleet.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P57_S1	Purchased services expense consists primarily of costs associated with the use of contract drivers and outsourced traction service in Europe, as well as port and terminal handling expenses in the U.K. Electricity used in train operations represents the cost of powering the electric locomotive fleet in the U.K. and Continental Europe.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P58_S0	Trackage rights expense represents payments made to track owners under open access regimes.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P58_S1	Income/(Loss) from Operations/Operating Ratio Income from operations from our U.K./European Operations was $31.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with a $2.0 million loss from operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P58_S2	The loss for the year ended December 31, 2014 included costs associated with the start-up of a significant new long-term customer contract that commenced in early 2014 to provide shuttle service between Rotterdam and the German border .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P58_S3	The operating ratio was 93.8% for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P58_S4	The prior year is not comparable because over 95% of the revenue and income from operations was generated from the recently acquired Freightliner business.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P59_S0	Our U.K./European Operations operate in an open access environment using primarily leased equipment.

1012620_16_ITEM7_P61_S0	Operating Expenses Total operating expenses for the year ended December 31, 2014 increased $29.0 million , or 2.4% , to $1,217.4 million , compared with $1,188.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P61_S1	The increase consisted of $35.6 million from new operations, partially offset by a decrease of $6.6 million from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P61_S2	The decrease from existing operations was primarily due to a $21.6 million decrease from the depreciation of foreign currencies relative to the United States dollar and decreases of $23.1 million in purchased services, $10.8 million in other expenses, $1.6 million in materials and $1.0 million in diesel fuel used in train operations, partially offset by increases of $27.5 million in labor and benefits, $14.0 million in depreciation and amortization, $4.1 million in trackage rights and $3.4 million in casualties and insurance.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P61_S3	The following table sets forth operating expenses for the year ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_16_ITEM7_P62_S0	Income from Operations/Operating Ratio Income from operations was $421.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $380.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P62_S1	Income from operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 included business development and related costs of $5.2 million and net gain on sale of assets of $5.1 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P62_S2	Income from operations for the year ended December 31, 2013 included $17.0 million of RailAmerica integration and acquisition-related costs and $1.6 million of business development and related costs, partially offset by net gain on sale of assets of $4.7 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P63_S0	Our operating ratio was 74.3% for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared with 75.8% for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P63_S1	While changes in foreign currency exchange rates can have a material impact on our operating revenues and operating expenses, the impact of these foreign currency translation effects should not have a material impact on our operating ratio.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S0	Interest Income Interest income was $1.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $4.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S1	The decrease in interest income was primarily related to the repayment and termination of our cross-currency swap agreements, see Note 9 , Derivative Financial Instruments , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S2	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report, for further details on the repayment and termination of our cross-currency swap agreement.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S3	Interest Expense Interest expense was $56.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $67.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S4	The decrease in interest expense was primarily due to lower borrowing costs consistent with our reduced leverage, the expiration of various interest rate swap agreements, the termination of our cross-currency swap agreements and reduced amortization of deferred financing fees resulting primarily from the refinancing of our credit agreement in May 2014.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S5	Interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2014 included the write-off of deferred financing fees of $4.6 million associated with the refinancing of our credit agreement.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S6	Provision for Income Taxes Our income tax provision for the year ended December 31, 2014 was $107.1 million , which represented 29.1% of income before income taxes.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S7	Our provision for income taxes for the year ended December 31, 2014 included a $3.9 million tax benefit as a result of receiving consent from the United States IRS to change a tax accounting method retroactively for companies acquired as a result of the RailAmerica acquisition.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S8	Included in our net income for the year ended December 31, 2013 was a $41.0 million benefit associated with the retroactive extension of the United States Short Line Tax Credit for fiscal year 2012.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S9	Since the extension became law in 2013, the 2012 impact was recorded in the first quarter of 2013.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S10	Excluding the $41.0 million retroactive benefit, our provision for income taxes was $87.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , which represented 27.4% of income before income taxes.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S11	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2014 was $260.8 million , compared with net income of $271.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S12	Our basic EPS were $4.71 with 55.3 million weighted average shares outstanding for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with basic EPS of $5.00 with 53.8 million weighted average shares outstanding for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S13	Our diluted EPS for the year ended December 31, 2014 were $4.58 with 57.0 million weighted average shares outstanding, compared with diluted EPS for the year ended December 31, 2013 of $4.79 with 56.7 million weighted average shares outstanding.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S14	On February 13, 2013, we converted all of our outstanding Series A-1 Preferred Stock into 5,984,232 shares of our Class A Common Stock.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P64_S15	The conversion resulted in an increase in our weighted average basic shares outstanding of 5,984,232 and 5,262,845 for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively.

1012620_16_ITEM7_P69_S0	The following table sets forth the changes in our North American Operations freight revenues by commodity group segregated into new operations and existing operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with the year ended December 31, 2013 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_16_ITEM7_P70_S0	Total traffic from our North American Operations increased 129,243 carloads, or 7.8% , for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P70_S1	The increase consisted of 92,349 carloads, or 5.6% , from existing operations and 36,894 carloads from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P70_S2	The increase in traffic from existing operations was principally due to increases of 32,248 carloads of coal and coke traffic, 22,863 carloads of minerals and stone traffic, 17,397 carloads of other commodity traffic, 9,559 carloads of agricultural products traffic, 8,253 carloads of metals traffic, 5,234 carloads of pulp and paper traffic and 4,804 carloads of food and kindred products traffic.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P71_S0	The following information discusses the significant changes in our North American Operations freight revenues from existing operations by commodity group excluding the impact of foreign currency.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P71_S1	Changes in average freight revenues per carload in a commodity group can be impacted by changes in customer rates, fuel surcharges as well as changes in the mix of customer traffic within a commodity group.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P71_S2	Average freight revenues per carload from our North American Operations increased 2.5% to $567 for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P71_S3	Agricultural products revenues increased $12.4 million , or 13.8% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P71_S4	Average freight revenues per carload increased 8.2%, which increased revenues by $7.2 million, and traffic volume increased 9,559 carloads, or 5.3%, which increased revenues by $5.2 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P71_S5	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased shipments in the midwestern and western United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S0	Autos and auto parts revenues decreased $2.3 million , or 9.0% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S1	Autos and auto parts traffic volume decreased 2,040 carloads, or 5.6%, which decreased revenues by $1.4 million, and average freight revenues per carload decreased 3.7%, which decreased revenues by $0.9 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S2	The decrease in carloads was primarily due to reduced railcar supply in the midwestern United States and Canada.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S3	Chemicals and plastics revenues increased $5.4 million , or 4.2% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S4	Chemicals and plastics average freight revenues per carload increased 3.3%, which increased revenues by $4.3 million, and traffic volume increased 1,352 carloads, which increased revenues by $1.1 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S5	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased chemical shipments to a mine in the western United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S6	Coal and coke revenues increased $15.7 million , or 14.2% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S7	Coal and coke traffic volume increased 32,248 carloads, or 10.0%, which increased revenues by $11.5 million and average freight revenues per carload increased 3.8%, which increased revenues by $4.3 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S8	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased demand for steam coal in the midwestern United States, partially offset by decreased coal shipments in the western United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S9	Food and kindred products revenues increased $2.9 million , or 9.0% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S10	Food and kindred products traffic volume increased 4,804 carloads, or 8.7%, which increased revenues $2.8 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S11	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased shipments in the western and midwestern United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S12	Lumber and forest products revenues increased $3.4 million , or 4.3% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S13	Lumber and forest products traffic volume increased 2,974 carloads, or 2.2%, which increased revenues by $1.8 million, and average freight revenues per carload increased 2.0%, which increased revenues by $1.6 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S14	The carload increase was primarily due to increased shipments of wood pellets, wood chips and finished lumber in the southern United States, partially offset by decreased shipments in Canada.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S15	Metallic ores revenues increased $1.4 million , or 8.8% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S16	Metallic ores traffic volume increased 1,892 carloads, or 9.4%, which increased revenues by $1.5 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S17	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased shipments of copper concentrate in the western United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S18	Metals revenues increased $3.9 million , or 3.1% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S19	Metals traffic volume increased 8,253 carloads, or 4.7%, which increased revenues by $5.8 million, while average freight revenues per carload decreased 1.5%, which decreased revenues by $1.9 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S20	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased shipments of steel in the midwestern and southern United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S21	Minerals and stone revenues increased $9.9 million , or 11.5% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S22	Minerals and stone traffic volume increased 22,863 carloads, or 14.1%, which increased revenues by $11.9 million, while average freight revenues per carload decreased 2.3%, which decreased revenues by $2.0 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S23	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased shipments of rock salt, frac sand, cement, construction aggregates and industrial minerals in North America.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S24	Pulp and paper revenues increased $5.8 million , or 5.2% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S25	Pulp and paper traffic volume increased 5,234 carloads, or 3.1%, which increased revenues by $3.5 million, and average freight revenues per carload increased 2.1%, which increased revenues by $2.3 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S26	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased shipments of container board in the United States, partially offset by decreased shipments of finished paper and wood pulp in Canada.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S27	Waste revenues decreased $4.3 million , or 18.8% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S28	Waste revenues average freight revenues per carload decreased 12.5%, which decreased revenues by $2.8 million, and traffic volume decreased 3,172 carloads, or 7.3%, which decreased revenues by $1.5 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S29	The decrease in carloads was primarily due to the closure of a waste facility in the midwestern United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S30	Other revenues increased $1.9 million , or 9.9% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S31	Other revenues traffic volume increased 17,397, or 24.6%, which increased revenues by $4.3 million, while average freight revenues per carload decreased 11.9%, which decreased revenues by $2.3 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S32	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased overhead Class I traffic in the central United States.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P72_S33	Freight revenues from all remaining commodities combined decreased by a net $0.3 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P73_S0	Freight-Related Revenues Excluding a $2.3 million decrease due to the impact of foreign currency depreciation, freight-related revenues from our North American Operations, which includes revenues from railcar switching, track access rights, crewing services, storage and other ancillary revenues related to the movement of freight, increased $1.4 million , or 0.6% , to $214.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P73_S1	The increase in freight-related revenues consisted of $3.8 million from new operations, partially offset by a decrease of $2.4 million from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P73_S2	All Other Revenues Excluding a $0.5 million decrease due to the depreciation of foreign currency, all other revenues from our North American Operations, which includes revenues from third-party car and locomotive repairs, property rentals, railroad construction and other ancillary revenues not directly related to the movement of freight, decreased $13.2 million , or 13.9% , to $82.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P73_S3	The decrease in all other revenues consisted of $14.3 million from existing operations, partially offset by $1.0 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P73_S4	The decrease in all other revenues from existing operations was primarily due to a decrease in construction revenues as a result of fewer third-party projects in 2014, which resulted from our previously disclosed decision to focus our construction resources on internal projects.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P73_S5	Operating Expenses Total operating expenses from our North American Operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 increased $28.6 million , or 3.0% , to $971.6 million , compared with $943.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P73_S6	The increase included $35.6 million from new operations, partially offset by a decrease of $7.0 million from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P73_S7	The decrease from existing operations was primarily due to the depreciation of the Canadian dollar relative to the United States dollar.

1012620_16_ITEM7_P74_S0	The following information discusses the significant changes in operating expenses of our North American Operations excluding a decrease of $6.8 million due to the impact from foreign currency depreciation.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P74_S1	Labor and benefits expense was $390.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $364.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $26.3 million , or 7.2% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P74_S2	The increase consisted of $16.5 million from existing operations and $9.8 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P74_S3	The increase from existing operations was primarily due to an increase in the average number of employees.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P74_S4	Our average number of employees increased for our existing operations primarily as a result of insourcing equipment maintenance activities in the midwestern United States and an increase in transportation employees as a result of higher traffic levels.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S0	Equipment rents expense was $70.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $65.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $4.4 million , or 6.8% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S1	The increase was primarily from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S2	Purchased services expense was $62.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $67.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $4.6 million , or 6.8% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S3	The decrease consisted of $7.7 million from existing operations, partially offset by $3.2 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S4	The decrease from existing operations was primarily due to a reduction in the level of third-party construction projects.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S5	Depreciation and amortization expense was $127.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $112.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $15.3 million , or 13.7% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S6	The increase consisted of $11.1 million from existing operations and $4.3 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S7	The increase from existing operations was primarily attributable to capital expenditures in 2013.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S8	The cost of diesel fuel used in train operations was $120.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $113.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $7.1 million , or 6.2% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S9	The increase consisted of $6.0 million from new operations and $1.1 million from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S10	The increase from existing operations consisted of $6.2 million due to a 5.7% increase in diesel fuel consumption, partially offset by $5.1 million due to a 4.4% decrease in average fuel cost per gallon.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S11	Casualties and insurance expense was $30.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $28.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $2.1 million , or 7.4% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S12	The increase consisted of $1.6 million from existing operations and $0.5 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S13	Materials expense was $69.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $73.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $3.7 million , or 5.0% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S14	The decrease consisted of $7.1 million from existing operations, partially offset by $3.4 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S15	The decrease from existing operations was primarily due to a reduction in the level of construction projects in 2014.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S16	Trackage rights expense was $28.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $28.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $0.5 million , or 1.9% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S17	The decrease was primarily attributable to existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S18	Other expenses were $75.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $87.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $11.8 million , or 13.5% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S19	The decrease consisted of $16.0 million from existing operations, partially offset by $4.2 million from new operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S20	The decrease from existing operations was primarily attributable to RailAmerica integration costs incurred in 2013.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S21	Income from Operations/Operating Ratio Income from operations from our North American Operations was $333.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $286.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S22	Income from operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 included business development and related costs of $4.9 million , partially offset by a $4.6 million net gain on sale of assets.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S23	Income from operations for the year ended December 31, 2013 included $17.0 million of RailAmerica integration and acquisition-related costs and $1.4 million of business development and related costs, partially offset by net gain on sale of assets of $4.3 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P75_S24	The operating ratio was 74.5% for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with 76.7% for the year ended December 31, 2013 .

1012620_16_ITEM7_P78_S1	The following table sets forth the changes in our Australian Operations freight revenues by commodity group for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with the year ended December 31, 2013 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_16_ITEM7_P79_S0	Total traffic from our Australian Operations decreased 8,204 carloads, or 3.5% , for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P79_S1	The traffic was entirely from existing operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P79_S2	The decrease was principally due to decreases of 7,573 carloads of agricultural products traffic, 3,355 carloads of minerals and stone traffic and 1,673 carloads of intermodal traffic , partially offset by a 4,407 carload increase in metallic ores traffic.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S0	The following information discusses the significant changes in our Australian Operations freight revenues by commodity group excluding the impact of foreign currency.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S1	Changes in average freight revenues per carload in a commodity group can be impacted by changes in customer rates and fuel surcharges, as well as changes in the mix of customer traffic within a commodity group.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S2	Average freight revenues per carload from our Australian Operations increased 3.9% to $1,069 for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S3	Changes in commodity mix increased average freight revenues 4.0%.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S4	Agricultural products revenues decreased $5.6 million , or 14.9% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S5	Agricultural traffic decreased 7,573 carloads, or 12.3%, which decreased revenues by $4.5 million, and average freight revenues per carload decreased 3.0%, which decreased revenues by $1.1 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S6	The decrease in carloads was primarily due to a late start to the harvest season.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S7	Metallic ores revenues increased $6.9 million , or 6.7% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S8	Metallic ores traffic volume increased 4,407 carloads, or 8.5%, which increased revenues by $8.5 million, while average freight revenues per carload decreased 1.6%, which decreased revenues by $1.7 million.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S9	The increase in carloads was primarily due to increased shipments of iron ore, manganese and copper ore.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S10	Freight revenues from all remaining commodities combined decreased by $0.5 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S11	Freight-Related Revenues Excluding a $3.7 million decrease due to the impact of foreign currency depreciation, freight-related revenues from our Australian Operations, which includes revenues from railcar switching, track access rights, crewing services, storage and other ancillary revenues related to the movement of freight, increased $1.3 million , or 2.4% , to $55.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S12	The increase in freight-related revenues, which was entirely from existing operations, included an increase in railcar switching revenue due to higher narrow gauge iron ore shipments, partially offset by the loss of track access income from an iron ore mine that ceased operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S13	All Other Revenues Excluding a $0.5 million decrease due to the impact of foreign currency depreciation, all other revenues from our Australian Operations, which includes revenue from third-party railcar and locomotive repairs, property rentals and other ancillary revenues not directly related to the movement of freight, increased $7.0 million , or 98.3% , to $14.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S14	The increase was primarily due to increased railcar maintenance for customers.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S15	Operating Expenses Total operating expenses from our Australian Operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 decreased $6.9 million , or 3.0% , to $222.9 million , compared with $229.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P80_S16	The decrease included a $14.8 million decrease due to the depreciation of foreign currency.

1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S0	The following information discusses the significant changes in operating expenses from our Australian Operations excluding a $14.8 million decrease due to the impact from foreign currency depreciation.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S1	Labor and benefits expense was $71.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $62.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $9.2 million , or 14.8% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S2	The increase in labor and benefits expense was due to an increase in our average number of employees primarily related to the insourcing of equipment maintenance activities.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S3	Purchased services expense was $34.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $48.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $14.8 million , or 30.3% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S4	The decrease in purchased services expense was primarily attributable to the insourcing of equipment maintenance activities.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S5	Depreciation and amortization was $28.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $25.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $2.8 million , or 11.0% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S6	The increase in depreciation and amortization expense was primarily due to capital expenditures in 2013.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S7	The cost of diesel fuel used in train operations was $26.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $29.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $2.6 million , or 9.1% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S8	The decrease consisted of $1.3 million due to a 4.1% increase in average fuel cost per gallon and $1.3 million due to a 5.3% decrease in diesel fuel consumption.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S9	Casualties and insurance expense was $10.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $9.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $1.2 million , or 12.8% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S10	The increase was primarily due to an increase in derailment expense.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S11	Materials expense was $7.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $2.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $5.1 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S12	The increase in materials expense was primarily attributable to the increase in materials purchased to support the insourcing of equipment maintenance activities.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S13	Trackage rights expense was $22.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $20.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $2.0 million , or 10.2% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S14	The increase in trackage rights expense was primarily attributable to expanded services for an iron ore customer that moves over a segment of track owned by a third party.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P82_S15	Other expenses were $12.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $8.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $4.9 million , or 61.4% , primarily resulting from third-party projects.

1012620_16_ITEM7_P83_S1	The decrease was primarily due to the net impact from foreign currency depreciation.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P83_S2	The operating ratio was 71.1% for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with 70.7% for the year ended December 31, 2013 .

1012620_16_ITEM7_P85_S0	Income/(Loss) from Operations Loss from operations from our U.K./European Operations was $2.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with a $1.0 million loss from operations for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P85_S1	The loss from our U.K./European Operations in 2013 included extra operating expenses incurred as a result of third party accidents, as well as higher staffing and training expenses incurred in preparation for a significant new long-term customer contract that commenced in early 2014 to provide shuttle service between Rotterdam and the German border.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P85_S2	In 2014, the loss widened as expected during the ramp-up period of the new shuttle service.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P85_S3	Liquidity and Capital Resources We had cash and cash equivalents on hand of $35.9 million and $59.7 million at December 31, 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P85_S4	Based on current expectations, we believe our cash and other liquid assets, anticipated future cash flows, availability under our credit agreement, access to debt and equity capital markets and sources of available financing will be sufficient to fund expected operating, capital and debt service requirements and other financial commitments for the foreseeable future.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P85_S5	At December 31, 2015 , we had long-term debt, including current portion, of $2,305.3 million , which comprised 47.8% of our total capitalization, and $575.7 million of unused borrowing capacity.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P85_S6	At December 31, 2014 , we had long-term debt, including current portion, totaling $1,615.4 million , which comprised 40.7% of our total capitalization.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2015 , we completed the acquisition of Freightliner for cash consideration of 492.1 million (or $733.0 million at the exchange rate on March 25, 2015).
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S1	We financed the acquisition through a combination of available cash and borrowings under the Credit Agreement (see Credit Agreement below).
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S2	During 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , we generated $475.1 million , $491.5 million and $413.5 million , respectively, of cash from operating activities.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S3	Changes in working capital decreased net cash flows from operating activities by $8.5 million , $3.6 million and $26.1 million in 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S4	The 2015 period included $33.2 million of cash used for Freightliner acquisition and integration costs.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S5	The 2013 period included $12.9 million in cash paid for expenses related to the integration of RailAmerica.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S6	During 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , our cash used in investing activities was $1,074.3 million , $509.8 million and $208.7 million , respectively.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S7	For 2015 , primary drivers of cash used in investing activities were $740.2 million of cash paid for acquisitions, including the acquisitions of Freightliner and Pinsly Arkansas, $371.5 million of cash used for capital expenditures, including $65.6 million for new business investments and $18.7 million of net cash paid for the settlement of the foreign currency forward purchase contracts related to the acquisition of Freightliner, partially offset by $41.7 million in cash received from grants from outside parties for capital spending and $10.4 million of insurance proceeds for the replacement of assets.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S8	For 2014 , primary drivers of cash used in investing activities were $331.5 million of cash used for capital expenditures, including $92.9 million for new business investments, $221.5 million of cash paid for acquisitions, predominately for the RCP E acquisition, partially offset by $28.0 million in cash received from grants from outside parties for capital spending, $8.0 million of insurance proceeds for the replacement of assets and $7.1 million in cash proceeds from the sale of property and equipment.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S9	For 2013 , primary drivers of cash used in investing activities were $249.3 million of cash used for capital expenditures, including $34.2 million for new business investments, partially offset by $33.9 million in cash received from grants from outside parties and $6.7 million in cash proceeds from the sale of property and equipment.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S10	During 2015 and 2014 , our cash provided by financing activities was $581.6 million and $15.2 million , respectively.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S11	During 2013 , our cash used in financing activities was $205.9 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S12	For 2015 , the primary driver of cash provided by financing activities was net proceeds of $586.2 million , which was predominately related to borrowings from the refinancing of the Credit Agreement in conjunction with our acquisition of Freightliner.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S13	For 2014 , the primary driver of cash flows provided by financing activities was net cash inflows of $13.9 million from exercises of stock-based awards.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P86_S14	For 2013 , the primary driver of cash used in financing activities was a net decrease in outstanding debt of $209.3 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P87_S0	Cash Repatriation At December 31, 2015 , we had cash and cash equivalents totaling $35.9 million , of which $28.3 million were held by our foreign subsidiaries.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P87_S1	We file a consolidated United States federal income tax return that includes all of our United States subsidiaries.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P87_S2	Each of our foreign subsidiaries files income tax returns in each of its respective countries.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P87_S3	No provision is made for the United States income taxes applicable to the undistributed earnings of controlled foreign subsidiaries as it is the intention of management to fully utilize those earnings in the operations of foreign subsidiaries.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P87_S4	If the earnings were to be distributed in the future, those distributions may be subject to United States income taxes (appropriately reduced by available foreign tax credits) and withholding taxes payable to various foreign countries; however, the amount of the tax and credits is not practicable to determine.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P87_S5	The amount of undistributed earnings of our controlled foreign subsidiaries as of December 31, 2015 was $322.5 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P88_S0	In anticipation of our acquisition of Freightliner, we entered into the Credit Agreement on March 20, 2015.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P89_S0	Australian term loan, a 101.7 million (or $152.2 million at the exchange rate on March 20, 2015) U.K. term loan and a $625.0 million revolving credit facility.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P89_S1	The revolving credit facility includes borrowing capacity for letters of credit and swingline loans.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P89_S2	The maturity date of each of our credit facilities under the Credit Agreement is March 31, 2020 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P90_S0	On September 30, 2015, we entered into Amendment No. 1 (the Amendment) to the Credit Agreement.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P90_S1	The Amendment added a senior secured leverage ratio covenant that requires us to comply with maximum ratios of senior secured indebtedness, subject, if applicable, to netting of certain cash and cash equivalents to earnings before income taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA).
1012620_16_ITEM7_P90_S2	For additional information regarding our Credit Agreement, Credit Agreement Amendment and the Prior Credit Agreement, see Note 8 , Long-Term Debt , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P90_S3	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P90_S4	On September 19, 2012, we issued 2,300,000 5.00% TEUs.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P90_S5	Each TEU initially consisted of a prepaid stock purchase contract (Purchase Contract) and a senior amortizing note due October 1, 2015 (Amortizing Note) issued by us, which had an initial principal amount of $14.1023 per Amortizing Note.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P90_S6	On each January 1, April 1, July 1 and October 1, we paid the holders of Amortizing Notes equal quarterly installments of $1.25 per Amortizing Note (except for the January 1, 2013 installment payment, which was $1.4167 per Amortizing Note), which cash payments in the aggregate were equivalent to a 5.00% cash payment per year with respect to each $100 stated amount of the TEUs.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P90_S7	On October 1, 2015, we settled the remaining balance of the amortizing note component of the TEUs for a total cash payment of $2.8 million .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P90_S8	In addition, we settled the prepaid stock purchase contract component of the TEUs with the delivery of 3,539,240 shares of our Class A Common Stock.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P91_S0	In 2010, as part of the acquisition of FreightLink Pty Ltd, Asia Pacific Transport Pty Ltd and related corporate entities (FreightLink Acquisition), we assumed debt with a carrying value of A$1.8 million (or $1.7 million at the exchange rate on December 1, 2010), which represented the fair value of an A$50.0 million (or $48.2 million at the exchange rate on December 1, 2010) non-interest bearing loan due in 2054 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P91_S1	As of December 31, 2015 , the carrying value of the loan was A$2.7 million (or $1.9 million at the exchange rate on December 31, 2015 ) with a non-cash imputed interest rate of 8.0% .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P92_S0	Equipment and Property Leases We enter into operating leases for railcars, locomotives and other equipment as well as real property.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P92_S1	We also enter into agreements with other railroads and other third parties to operate over certain sections of their track, whereby we pay a per car fee to use the track or make an annual lease payment.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P92_S2	The costs associated with operating leases are expensed as incurred.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P92_S3	The increase in leased equipment in 2015 was attributable to our acquisition of Freightliner, which primarily relies upon leased railcars and locomotives.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P93_S0	The number of railcars and locomotives leased by us as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 was as follows:
1012620_16_ITEM7_P94_S0	Our operating lease expense for equipment and real property leases and expense for the use of other railroad and other third parties' track for the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 was as follows (dollars in thousands):
1012620_16_ITEM7_P95_S0	We are party to several lease agreements with Class I carriers and other third parties to operate over various rail lines in North America, with varied expirations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P95_S1	Certain of these lease agreements have annual lease payments.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P95_S2	Revenues from railroads we lease from Class I carriers and other third parties accounted for approximately 7% of our 2015 total revenues.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P95_S3	Leases from Class I railroads and other third parties that are subject to expiration in each of the next 10 years represent less than 2% of our annual revenues for the year of expiration based on our operating revenues for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1012620_16_ITEM7_P96_S0	We have an effective shelf registration statement on file with the SEC for an indeterminate number of securities that is effective for three years (expires September 14, 2018), around which time we expect to file a replacement shelf registration statement.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P96_S1	Under this universal shelf registration statement, we have the capacity to offer and sell from time to time securities, including common stock, debt securities, preferred stock, warrants and units.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P97_S0	Grants from Outside Parties Our railroads have received a number of project grants from federal, provincial, state and local agencies and other outside parties (e.g., customers) for upgrades and construction of rail lines and upgrades of locomotives.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P97_S1	We use the grant funds as a supplement to our normal capital programs.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P97_S2	In return for the grants, the railroads pledge to maintain various levels of service and improvements on the rail lines that have been upgraded or constructed.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P97_S3	We believe the levels of service and improvements required under the grants are reasonable.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P97_S4	However, we can offer no assurance that grants from outside parties will continue to be available or that, even if available, our railroads will be able to obtain them.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P98_S0	Insurance and Third-Party Claims Accounts receivable from insurance and other third-party claims was $26.6 million and $26.9 million as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 , respectively.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P98_S1	Accounts receivable from insurance and other third-party claims at December 31, 2015 included $12.8 million from our North American Operations, $8.1 million from our Australian Operations and $5.7 million from our U.K./European Operations.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P98_S2	The balance from our North American Operations resulted predominately from our anticipated insurance recoveries associated with a derailment in Alabama (the Aliceville Derailment) in November 2013 and a trestle fire in Oregon in August 2015.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P98_S3	The balance from our Australian Operations resulted from our anticipated insurance recoveries associated with derailments in Australia in 2012.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P98_S4	The balance from our U.K./European Operations resulted primarily from our anticipated insurance recoveries associated with a rail-related collision in Germany in 2014 that occurred prior to our acquisition of Freightliner.
1012620_16_ITEM7_P98_S5	We received proceeds from insurance totaling $10.4 million , $13.6 million and $11.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
