1012620_18_ITEM7_P161_S0	An off-balance sheet arrangement includes any contractual obligation, agreement or transaction involving an unconsolidated entity under which we (1) have made guarantees, (2) have a retained or contingent interest in transferred assets, or a similar arrangement, that serves as credit, liquidity or market risk support to that entity for such assets, (3) have an obligation under certain derivative instruments, or (4) have any obligation arising out of a material variable interest in such an entity that provides financing, liquidity, market risk or credit risk support to us, or that engages in leasing or hedging services with us.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P161_S1	Our off-balance sheet arrangements as of December 31, 2017 consisted of operating lease obligations, which are included in the contractual obligations table above.

1012620_18_ITEM7_P163_S0	The results of operations of our foreign entities are maintained in the local currency (including, the Australian dollar, the British pound, the Canadian dollar, the Euro and the Polish zloty) and then translated into United States dollars based on the exchange rate at the end of the period for balance sheet items and, for the statement of operations, at the average exchange rate for the statement period.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P163_S1	When comparing the effects of average foreign currency exchange rates on operating revenues and operating expenses during the year ended December 31, 2017 versus the year ended December 31, 2016 , foreign currency translation had a net positive impact on our consolidated operating revenues and a net negative impact on our consolidated operating expenses due to the weakening of the British pound relative to the United States dollar, partially offset by the strengthening of the Australian and Canadian dollars and the Euro relative to the United States dollar for the year ended December 31, 2017 .
1012620_18_ITEM7_P164_S0	The following tables reflect the exchange rates used to translate the foreign entities respective local currency into United States dollars as of December 31, 2017 and 2016 , and for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 :
1012620_18_ITEM7_P165_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires management to use judgment and to make estimates and assumptions that affect business combinations, reported assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P165_S1	Management uses its judgment in making significant estimates in the areas of recoverability and useful life of assets, as well as liabilities for casualty claims and income taxes.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P165_S2	Actual results could materially differ from those estimates.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P166_S0	The following critical accounting policies and use of estimates should be read in conjunction with Note 2 , Significant Accounting Policies , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P166_S1	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P167_S0	We account for businesses we acquire using the acquisition method of accounting.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P167_S1	Under this method, all acquisition-related costs are expensed as incurred.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P168_S0	We record the underlying net assets at their respective acquisition-date fair values.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P168_S1	As part of this process, we identify and attribute values and estimated lives to property and equipment and intangible assets acquired.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P168_S2	These determinations involve significant estimates and assumptions, including those with respect to future cash flows, discount rates and asset lives, and therefore require considerable judgment.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P168_S3	These determinations affect the amount of depreciation and amortization expense recognized in future periods.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P168_S4	The results of operations of acquired businesses are included in the consolidated statements of operations beginning on the respective business's acquisition date.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P169_S0	Property and Equipment We record property and equipment at cost.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P169_S1	We capitalize major renewals or improvements, but routine maintenance and repairs are expensed when incurred.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P169_S2	We incur maintenance and repair expenses to keep our operations safe and fit for existing purpose.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P169_S3	Major renewals or improvements to property and equipment, however, are undertaken to extend the useful life or increase the functionality of the asset, or both.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P170_S0	When assessing spending for classification among capital or expense, we evaluate the substance of the respective spending.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P170_S1	For example, costs incurred to modify a railroad bridge, either through individual projects or pre-established multi-year programs, which substantially upgrade the bridge's capacity to carry increased loads and/or to allow for a carrying speed beyond the original or existing capacity of the bridge, are capitalized.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P170_S2	However, costs for replacement of routinely wearable bridge components, such as plates or bolts, are expensed as incurred.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P170_S3	Other than a de minimis threshold under which costs are expensed as incurred, we do not apply pre-defined capitalization thresholds when assessing spending for classification among capital or expense.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P171_S0	Unlike the Class I railroads that operate over extensive contiguous rail networks, our short line and regional railroads are generally geographically dispersed businesses that transport freight over relatively short distances.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P171_S1	Our largest category of capital expenditures is for track line upgrades, expansion and replacement, where we will utilize both our employees and professional contractors in completing these capital projects.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P172_S0	Costs that are directly attributable to self-constructed assets (including overhead costs) are capitalized.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P172_S1	Direct costs that are capitalized as part of self-constructed assets include materials, labor and equipment.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P172_S2	Indirect costs are capitalized if they clearly relate to the construction of the asset.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P172_S3	We also generally do not incur significant rail grinding or ballast cleaning expenses.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P172_S4	However, if and when such costs are incurred, they are expensed.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P172_S5	The following table sets forth our total net capitalized major renewals and improvements versus our total maintenance and repair expense for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_18_ITEM7_P173_S0	We depreciate our property and equipment using the straight-line method over the useful lives of the property and equipment.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P173_S1	The following table sets forth the estimated useful lives of our major classes of property and equipment:
1012620_18_ITEM7_P174_S0	We continually evaluate whether events and circumstances have occurred that indicate that the carrying amounts of our long-lived tangible assets may not be recoverable.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P174_S1	When factors indicate that an asset or asset group may not be recoverable, we use an estimate of the related undiscounted future cash flows over the remaining life of such asset or asset group in measuring whether or not impairment has occurred.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P174_S2	If we identify impairment of an asset, we would report a loss to the extent that the carrying value of the related asset exceeds the fair value less the cost to sell such asset, as determined by valuation techniques applicable in the circumstances.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P175_S0	Losses from impairment of assets are charged to net loss/(gain) on sale and impairment of assets within operating expenses.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P176_S0	Gains or losses on sales, including sales of assets removed during track and equipment upgrade projects, or losses incurred through other dispositions, such as unanticipated retirement or destruction, are credited or charged to net loss/(gain) on sale and impairment of assets within operating expenses.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P176_S1	Gains are recorded when realized if the sale value exceeds the remaining carrying value of the respective property and equipment.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P176_S2	If the estimated salvage value is less than the remaining carrying value, we record the loss incurred equal to the respective asset's carrying value less salvage value.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P177_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2017, we recorded a $5.9 million non-cash charge related to the impairment of track assets on idle branch lines in South Australia.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P177_S1	During the year ended December 31, 2016, we recorded a $13.0 million non-cash charge related to the impairment of an idle rolling-stock maintenance facility resulting from Arrium, an iron ore customer in Australia, entering voluntary administration.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P177_S2	For additional information regarding Arrium, see Note 3 , Changes in Operations , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P177_S3	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P177_S4	There were no material losses incurred through other dispositions from unanticipated or unusual events for the year ended December 31, 2015.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P178_S0	Grants from Outside Parties Grants from outside parties are recorded within deferred items - grants from outside parties, and are amortized as a reduction to depreciation expense over the same period during which the associated assets are depreciated.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P179_S0	Goodwill We review the carrying value of goodwill at least annually to assess impairment since these assets are not amortized.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P179_S1	We perform our annual impairment assessment as of November 30 of each year.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P179_S2	Additionally, we review the carrying value of goodwill whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that its carrying amount may not be recoverable.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P179_S3	No impairment was recognized for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2015 , as a result of our annual impairment assessment.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P179_S4	In 2016, in conjunction with our annual impairment assessment of goodwill combined with previously discussed efforts to address challenges with our Continental Europe intermodal business, ERS, we recorded an impairment of goodwill of $14.5 million .
1012620_18_ITEM7_P179_S5	See Note 3 , Changes in Operations , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P179_S6	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report for additional information regarding ERS.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P180_S0	For goodwill, a two-step impairment model is used.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P180_S1	The first step compares the fair value of a respective reporting unit with its carrying amount, including goodwill.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P180_S2	The second step measures the goodwill impairment loss as the excess of recorded goodwill over its implied fair value.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P181_S0	The determination of fair value involves significant management judgment including assumptions about operating results, business plans, income projections, anticipated future cash flows and market data.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P182_S0	Impairment losses are expensed when incurred and are charged to net loss/(gain) on sale and impairment of assets within operating expenses.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P183_S0	Amortizable Intangible Assets We perform an impairment test on amortizable intangible assets when specific impairment indicators are present.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P183_S1	We have amortizable intangible assets valued primarily as operational network rights, customer contracts and relationships and track access agreements.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P183_S2	These intangible assets are generally amortized on a straight-line basis over the expected economic longevity of the facility served, the customer relationship, or the length of the contract or agreement including expected renewals.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P183_S3	In 2016, in conjunction with our annual impairment assessment of goodwill combined with previously disclosed efforts to address challenges with ERS, we recorded an impairment of a customer-related intangible asset of $4.1 million .
1012620_18_ITEM7_P183_S4	See Note 3 , Changes in Operations , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P183_S5	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report for additional information regarding ERS.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P184_S0	Derailment and Property Damages, Personal Injuries and Third-Party Claims We maintain global liability and property insurance coverage to mitigate the financial risk of providing rail and rail-related services.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P184_S1	Our liability policies cover railroad employee injuries, personal injuries associated with grade crossing accidents and accidents involving passengers and other third-party claims associated with our operations.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P184_S2	Damages associated with sudden releases of hazardous materials, including hazardous commodities transported by rail, and expenses related to evacuation as a result of a railroad accident are also covered under our liability policies.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P184_S3	Our liability policies currently have self-insured retentions of up to $2.5 million per occurrence.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P185_S0	Our property policies cover property and equipment that we own, as well as property in our care, custody and control.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P185_S1	Our property policies currently have various self-insured retentions, which vary based on the type and location of the incident, that are currently up to $2.5 million per occurrence.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P185_S2	The property policies also provide business interruption insurance arising from covered events.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P185_S3	The self-insured retentions under our policies may change with each annual insurance renewal depending on our loss history, the size and make-up of our Company and general insurance market conditions.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P185_S4	We also maintain ancillary insurance coverage for other risks associated with rail and rail-related services, including insurance for employment practices, directors and officers liability, workers compensation, pollution, auto claims, crime and road haulage liability, among others.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P186_S0	Accruals for claims are recorded in the period when such claims are determined to be probable and estimable.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P186_S1	These estimates are updated in future periods as information develops.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P187_S0	Defined Benefit Plans We sponsor certain defined benefit plans covering eligible employees.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P187_S1	We engage independent actuaries to compute amounts of liabilities and expenses related to these plans subject to the assumptions that we determine are appropriate based on historical trends, current market rates and future projections.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P187_S2	These assumptions include, but are not limited to the selection of a discount rate, expected long-term rate of return on plan assets, rate of future compensation increases, inflation volatility and mortality.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P187_S3	For additional information regarding these plans, see Note 11 , U.K. Pension Plan , and Note 12 , Other Employee Benefit Programs , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P187_S4	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P188_S0	Income Taxes We file a consolidated United States federal income tax return, which includes all of our United States subsidiaries.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P188_S1	Each of our foreign subsidiaries files appropriate income tax returns in each of its respective countries.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P189_S0	The provision for, or benefit from, income taxes includes deferred taxes resulting from temporary differences using a balance sheet approach.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P189_S1	Such temporary differences result primarily from differences in the carrying value of assets and liabilities for financial reporting and tax purposes.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P190_S0	Future realization of deferred income tax assets is dependent upon our ability to generate sufficient taxable income.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P190_S1	We evaluate on a quarterly basis whether, based on all available evidence, the deferred income tax assets will be realizable.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P191_S0	Valuation allowances are established when it is estimated that it is more likely than not that the tax benefit of a deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P191_S1	On December 22, 2017, the TCJA was enacted into law.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P191_S2	The TCJA reduced the United States federal corporate income tax rate to 21% from 35% effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2017 .
1012620_18_ITEM7_P191_S3	Additionally, the TCJA requires United States companies to compute a one-time transition (toll) tax on earnings of certain foreign subsidiaries that were previously deferred for United States federal income tax purposes.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P191_S4	We have estimated the impact of the reduction in the United States federal corporate tax rate to be a reduction to our net deferred tax liabilities of approximately $394 million , which represents a decrease in corporate income taxes expected to be paid in the future.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P191_S5	We have also estimated the toll tax to be approximately $22 million payable over an eight-year period beginning in 2018.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P192_S0	Each of our foreign subsidiaries files income tax returns in each of its respective countries.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P192_S1	No provision is made for certain taxes applicable to the undistributed earnings of our foreign subsidiaries as it is the intention of management to fully utilize those earnings in the operations of foreign subsidiaries.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P192_S2	The amount of undistributed earnings of our foreign subsidiaries as of December 31, 2017 was $237.9 million .
1012620_18_ITEM7_P192_S3	If the earnings were to be distributed in the future, those distributions would not be subject to United States federal corporate income tax but may result in foreign exchange gains and losses and be subject to other taxes and credits, including United States state taxes and withholding taxes payable to various foreign countries; however, the amount of the tax is not practicable to determine.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P192_S4	For additional information regarding our income taxes, see Note 13 , Income Taxes , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P192_S5	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P193_S0	Recently Issued Accounting Standards See Note 20 , Recently Issued Accounting Standards , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_18_ITEM7_P193_S1	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The following tables set forth the primary drivers of our interest expense, net, for our North American Operations, Australia Operations and U.K./European Operations for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P1_S0	(a) Intercompany borrowing and lending activity is eliminated in consolidation.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P1_S1	(b) Interest expense on other instruments reflects interest on capital leases and certain fees related to our credit facilities.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Our interest rate risk results from variable interest rate debt obligations, where an increase in interest rates would result in lower earnings and increased cash outflows.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The following table presents principal payments on our debt obligations, related weighted average annual interest rates by expected maturity dates and estimated fair values as of December 31, 2017 (dollars in thousands):
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The variable interest rates presented in the table above are based on the implied forward rates in the yield curve for borrowings denominated using Australia BBSY and BBR, Canada BA, Euro LIBOR and United States LIBOR (as of December 31, 2017 ).
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P3_S1	BBSY is the Bank Bill Swap Bid Rate, which we believe is generally considered the Australian equivalent to LIBOR.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P3_S2	BBR is the Bankers Buyers Rate, which we believe is generally considered analogous with BBSY.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The borrowing margin is composed of a weighted average of 1.50% for Canadian, European and United States borrowings under our Credit Agreement.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P4_S1	The borrowing margin is composed of a weighted average of 2.78% for our Australian term loan under our Australian Credit Agreement and 4.50% for our Partner Loan Agreement.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P4_S2	To the extent not mitigated by interest rate swap agreements, based on the table above, assuming a one percentage point increase in market interest rates, annual interest expense on our variable rate debt would increase by approximately $12.7 million under our Credit Agreement and $3.1 million under our Australian Credit Agreement and Partner Loan Agreement.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P5_S0	As of December 31, 2017 , our foreign subsidiaries had the United States dollar equivalent of $1.1 billion of third-party debt denominated in the local currencies in which our foreign subsidiaries operate, including the Australian dollar, the British pound, the Canadian dollar and the Euro.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The debt service obligations associated with this foreign currency debt are generally funded directly from those foreign operations.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P5_S2	As a result, foreign currency risk related to this portion of our debt service payments is limited.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P5_S3	However, in the event the foreign currency debt service is not paid by our foreign subsidiaries and is paid by United States subsidiaries, we may face exchange rate risk if the Australian dollar, the British pound, the Canadian dollar or the Euro were to appreciate relative to the United States dollar and require higher United States dollar equivalent cash.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P6_S0	We are also exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risk related to our foreign subsidiaries, including non-functional currency intercompany debt, typically associated with intercompany debt from our United States subsidiaries to our foreign subsidiaries, associated with acquisitions and any timing difference between announcement and closing of an acquisition of a foreign business.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P6_S1	To mitigate currency exposures of non-United States dollar-denominated acquisitions, we may enter into foreign currency forward purchase contracts.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P6_S2	To mitigate currency exposures related to non-functional currency denominated intercompany debt, we may enter into cross-currency swaps or foreign currency forward contracts for periods consistent with the underlying debt.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S0	In determining the fair value of the derivative contract, the significant inputs to valuation models are quoted market prices of similar instruments in active markets.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S1	However, cross-currency swap contracts and foreign currency forward contracts used to mitigate exposures on foreign currency intercompany debt may not qualify for hedge accounting.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S2	In cases where the cross-currency swap contracts and foreign currency forward contracts do not qualify for hedge accounting, we believe that such instruments are closely correlated with the underlying exposure, thus reducing the associated risk.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S3	The gains or losses from changes in the fair value of derivative instruments that do not qualify for hedge accounting are recognized in current period earnings within other income, net.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S4	For additional information regarding our Derivative Financial Instruments, see Note 9 , Derivative Financial Instruments , to our Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in "Part IV Item 15.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S5	Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules" of this Annual Report.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S6	Deferred Consideration On March 25, 2015, as part of the Freightliner acquisition, we recorded a contingent liability within other long-term liabilities of 24.2 million (or $36.0 million at the exchange rate on March 25, 2015).
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S7	This contingent liability represented the aggregate fair value of the shares transferred to us by the Management Shareholders representing an economic interest of approximately 6% on the acquisition date at the Freightliner acquisition price per share, in exchange for the right to receive cash consideration for the representative economic interest in the future (deferred consideration).
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S8	We bought out this deferred consideration in November 2017 with the issuance of 238,201 shares of the Company's Class A Common Stock with a grant date fair value of $17.5 million , as well as 2.1 million (or $2.9 million at the exchange rate on December 31, 2017 ) in cash to be paid in March 2018.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S9	These shares have time-based contractual restrictions on their transfer until March 2018, March 2019 and March 2020.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S10	In addition, we issued a note payable with a 6.3 million (or $8.6 million at the exchange rate on December 31, 2017 ) face value ( 5.7 million fair value, or $7.7 million at the exchange rate on December 31, 2017 ) to certain management holders to buy out a portion of the deferred consideration.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S11	This note is payable in three annual installments starting in March 2018.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P7_S12	We recorded a net $8.9 million gain on the buyout of the deferred consideration in November 2017.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P8_S0	Sensitivity to Diesel Fuel Prices We are exposed to fluctuations in diesel fuel prices since an increase in the price of diesel fuel would result in lower earnings and cash outflows.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P8_S1	For the year ended December 31, 2017 , fuel costs for fuel used in operations represented 8.1% of our total operating expenses.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P8_S2	As of December 31, 2017 , we had not entered into any hedging transactions to manage this diesel fuel risk.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P8_S3	We receive fuel surcharges and other rate adjustments that offset the majority of the impact of higher fuel prices, with a lag of up to four months.
1012620_18_ITEM7A_P8_S4	As of December 31, 2017 , each one percentage point change in the price of diesel fuel would result in a $1.6 million change in our annual operating income to the extent not offset by higher fuel surcharges and/or rates.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P0_S0	On May 3, 2017, we completed the acquisition of Pentalver.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P0_S1	We extended our oversight and monitoring processes that support our internal control over financial reporting, as appropriate, to include Pentalver's financial position, results of operations and cash flow into our consolidated financial statements from the date of acquisition through December 31, 2017 .
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P0_S2	We are continuing to integrate the acquired operations of Pentalver into our overall internal control over financial reporting and related processes.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P0_S3	Except as disclosed in this paragraph, there were no other changes in our internal control over financial reporting (as the term is defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Exchange Act) during the three months ended December 31, 2017 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P1_S0	REPORT OF MANAGEMENT ON INTERNAL CONTROL OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING Management of Genesee Wyoming Inc. is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) or 15d-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Our internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that:
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P2_S0	provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of assets that could have a material effect on the consolidated financial statements.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management assessed the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2017 .
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Management based this assessment on criteria for effective internal control over financial reporting described in the Internal Control-Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P4_S0	The Company's internal controls over financial reporting, established and maintained by management, are under the general oversight of the Company's Audit Committee.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Management's assessment included an evaluation of the design of our internal control over financial reporting and testing of the operating effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P4_S2	Consistent with the guidance issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission that an assessment of a recently acquired business may be omitted from management's report on internal control over financial reporting in the year of acquisition, management excluded an assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting related to Pentalver.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P5_S0	The Company acquired Pentalver in a business combination on May 3, 2017.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P5_S1	Pentalver's total assets represented 2% of Genesee Wyoming Inc.'s consolidated total assets as of December 31, 2017 .
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P5_S2	Pentalver's total revenues and operating income for the period May 3, 2017 through December 31, 2017 represented less than 5% and 1% of Genesee Wyoming Inc.'s revenues and operating income, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2017.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P5_S3	Based on this assessment, management determined that, as of December 31, 2017 , we maintained effective internal control over financial reporting.
1012620_18_ITEM9A_P5_S4	PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, which has audited and reported on the consolidated financial statements contained in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, has audited the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting as stated in their report, which is included herein under "Part IV.
1012620_18_ITEM10_P0_S0	We have adopted a Code of Ethics and Conduct that applies to all directors, officers and employees, including our Chief Executive Officer, our Chief Financial Officer, and our Chief Accounting Officer and Global Controller.
1012620_18_ITEM10_P0_S1	The Code of Ethics and Conduct is available on the Governance page of the Company's Internet website at www.gwrr.com.
1012620_18_ITEM10_P0_S2	We intend to post any amendments to the Code of Ethics and Conduct and any waivers that are required to be disclosed by the rules of either the SEC or the NYSE on our Internet website within the required time period.
